We all have that one friend who never fucking sleeps. Like I don't know if he's part vampire or a fucking robot. You ask him, yo, you gonna sleep tonight? And he looks at you dead in the eyes like sleep is for weaklings, bro. We'll be chilling at like 2:00am and he's just wide awake scrolling on his phone acting like he's some kind of badass. And I'm over here like, dude, you're gonna crash eventually. And he just laughs like sleep is a myth or something. But it gets worse the next day he's somehow still full of energy looking like he's ready to fight a fucking bear. And I can barely get out of bed without turning into a zombie, bro. How does your body not just give up? You're walking around like some kind of immortal anime character and I swear the government should be studying you. And the worst part, he flexes it. Oh yeah, I didn't sleep last night. Congrats bro. You're tired. Oh wait, no, you're not. Meanwhile, I yawn every five seconds like a human malfunctioning. Give it five years and he's gonna be running marathons at 3:00am while the rest of us are still crying over our alarms get up.
NA

Why are schools banning phones like we're in prison? Like, bro, the second the bell rings, teachers act like we're trying to smuggle contraband across the border. They see a phone, and suddenly they're the FBI and their excuses. It's a distraction, bro. So is Kyle trying to balance a pencil on his upper lip for 40 minutes. Nobody banned that. It hurts your focus, and staring at a wall for 50 minutes during a lecture on mitochondria is supposed to build character? The worst part is how dramatic they make it. They'll stand in front of the class and say, this is for your own good, like they're saving us from some evil curse. Bro, it's TikTok, not black magic. And don't even get me started on those phone jails. Those little pouches they lock your phone in like it's doing a life sentence. You can hear it buzzing, crying for help, but you can't touch it. It's like watching your child get kidnapped. Then the teachers will pull the classic, back in my day, we didn't need phones. Yeah, back in your day, you also thought smoking indoors was fine and cars didn't have seatbelts. Times change, UNC. This isn't school, it's a boot camp. I'm completely cooked. Follow for more daily rants.
NA

I don't care what anyone says, there is nothing in this world more disrespectful than a phone charger that decides it only wants to work if you fold it like origami, rub it three times, and whisper a prayer to the tech gods. Like bro, are you a charger or a puzzle? Every single time I plug it in, it's like flipping a coin with my life on the line. I plug it in and the phone's like charging, not charging, charging, not charging. Bro, make up your mind. Why are you playing hard to get? You are a cable. You have one job. And don't let it be night time either. You're in bed, lights off, trying to sleep, and now you're having to hang your phone half off the edge of the table, hold the charger with your foot, and balance a water bottle on top of it just to keep it charging. And if you breathe too hard. Boom. Disconnected. Back to 2%. Game over. Like, who manufactured this thing? A leprechaun with commitment issues. Why do I have to enter a cheat code for electricity? And the worst part? It's always that one charger in the house. You don't want to throw it away because it technically still works, but it also technically ruins your life daily. So now you're telling your friends, hey, don't move the cable or the whole house might explode. Like bro, this is not a medical ventilator, this is a phone. Why is this situation so tense? And don't even get me started. When someone else tries to use it, they plug it in casually like, oh, it's not working. Yeah, because you didn't turn it 74 degrees northwest with the tabletilt and the moon phases aligned. I hate it here.

Put a finger down if you've ever thought of killing someone. Angry test. If you put more than five fingers down, you have serious anger issues. Put a finger down. If you've slammed a door or an object of anger, put a finger down. If you've ever cried out of anger, put a finger down. If you've ever raised your voice in an argument, put a finger down. If you've ever been angry on the first person who pops up after you click share and then more, put a finger down. If you've broken something out of anger, put a finger down. If you've had a heated argument with your friend or a family member, put a finger down. If you've ever punched a wall to get of some anger, put a finger down. If your face always looks angry, put a finger down. If you've ever sent an angry text and regretted it later, comment how many fingers you got down and follow for more.

What's the dumbest reason your daughter stopped talking to you? Oh, honey, let me tell you about the time my daughter didn't talk to me for two whole weeks because I betrayed her trust over a damn chicken nugget. So my daughter Lila, she's 14, has the attitude of a Beverly Hills housewife and the budget of a toddler. This girl acts like she's the CEO of the household, tells me things like, mom, please don't embarrass me in front of my friends. Just stand still and blink like, ma'am, you live in my uterus rent free for nine months. Show some respect. Anyway, she decides she's going vegan. Great. I support her. I buy tofu, almond milk, overpriced plant nuggets that taste like regret, the whole shebang. Do I understand it? No. But I'm a supportive queen. But then one night it's 1:00am, I'm watching reality TV in the dark and I get hungry. I open the freezer and see those dino shaped chicken nuggets she begged for last year and never ate. So I pop like 4 in the air fryer. I'm minding my business, living my best life life. And guess what? I forget to hide the evidence. Next morning she walks into the kitchen, sniffs the air like a bloodhound and goes, did you eat meat in this house? I said, um, maybe. She gasps like I just committed war crimes. You ate dead animals while I was sleeping. I said, baby girl, they were shaped like Dinosaurs, they're barely meat. Calm down. She grabs her reusable water bottle, slams it on the counter and yells, this is why the planet's dying, mom, because of people like you who can't control their midnight cravings. I said, okay, Greta Thunberg, relax. She storms off to her room and text me from down the hall. We're not speaking. This is a betrayal. I text back, fine, more dino nuggets from. She leaves me on read y'all. Two weeks she wouldn't speak to me, not even when I stubbed my toe and screamed so loud the neighbors checked on me. She just walked past me with her Hydro flask and judgmental aura. But then get this, one day I come home early from work. I walk into the kitchen and there she is standing in front of the microwave holding a plate with three dino nuggets. She's caught midbite. We lock eyes, time freezes. She goes, they don't count if they're Dinosaur shaped. I said, excuse me. She wipes her mouth like a criminal and goes, don't tell dad. I said, oh, I'm telling everyone. She bribes me with her leftover Starbucks gift card and begs for mercy. I post the photo in our family group chat. Anyway, catch then our little activist caught mid murder. Her grandpa replied, meet runs in the family. Her uncle sent a Dinosaur emoji. Now she talks to me again, but only if I swear never to bring it up again. And in front Of her friends. So what do I do? Oh, I bring it up at every chance, especially when they start talking about saving the turtles. Because if you're gonna give me the silent treatment over dino nuggets, you better be ready for extinction level consequences.

My stepfather called me worthless at graduation, so I saved his voicemail for the day I bought his dream house. I was valedictorian, full ride to Stanford. But all my stepfather could focus on was the empty seat where my biological father should have been sitting. After the ceremony, he pulled me aside behind the gymnasium. His face was red with that particular rage he reserved for moments when I reminded him that I wasn't his. You think you're so smart, he pissed, gripping my cap so hard the tassel snapped. Walking across that stage like you accomplished something, your real dad didn't even show up because deep down everyone knows what I know, you're worthless. Mom stood 20 feet away pretending not to see. She perfected that skill over the years. That night, drunk on wine and self importance, he left me a voicemail. I almost deleted it immediately. Instead, something made me save it. His slurred words about how college would humble me, how I'd come crawling back begging for his approval, how I'd never amount to anything without his guidance. Stanford was everything he said it wouldn't be. I thrived, made Dean's list every semester. By junior year, I was already being recruited by investment firms. During spring break of my senior year, I found my stepfather in his study surrounded by real estate magazines and architectural plans. He was obsessing over the same Victorian mansion that had been for sale in our town's historic district for Three years asking price was $2.8 million, completely beyond his reach as a middle management insurance adjuster. Someday, he told mom as I passed by, when my promotion comes through, this house represents everything I've worked for. He drive past it every weekend, slowing down to stare at the wrap around porch and turret windows. It consumed him the way some people obsess over celebrities. After graduation, I moved to New York. Within two years, I was making more money than my stepfather would see in a decade. I bought a penthouse in Manhattan, built a life he said I'd never have. But I kept thinking about that house. Last month, the Victorian was back on the market. The price had dropped to $2.4 million. I flew home that weekend and toured it with a realtor. Crown molding, original hardwood floors, a library with built in shelves reaching the ceiling. I could see why my stepfather had dreamed about it. I made an all cash offer that afternoon. The closing was scheduled for a Thursday. I drove to my mother's house afterward, the deed still warm in my hands. My stepfather was in his usual spot on the recliner watching cable news and complaining about mortgage rates. Remember that Victorian you always wanted, I asked casually. His head snapped up. The Whitmore house, what about it? I bought it today. The color drained from his face. Mom stopped folding.

What's the funniest thing someone has said while high on anesthesia? Last month, I took my girlfriend Ebony to get knee surgery after she tore her ACL playing soccer. My mom insisted on coming to the hospital because she wanted to support Ebony. Ebony goes into surgery and everything goes fine. When she wakes up in recovery, she's completely loopy from the anesthesia. The nurse warns us she might be a little confused and say some strange things. My mom immediately perks up. Oh, this should be interesting. Ebony opens her eyes and sees me first. Jake, you're so handsome, like a beautiful potato. Thanks, babe. How are you feeling? I feel like I'm floating. Am I floating? Are we in space? My mom laughs. No, sweetie, you're in the hospital. Ebony turns to look at my mom and her eyes go wide. Oh, my God. It's Jake's mom. You're so pretty. You look like Jake but with better hair. My mom is eating this up. Thank you, Ebony. I have something really important to tell you, Ebony says. Seriously? What's that, honey? Ebony motions for my mom to come closer. Come here. I need to whisper something in your ear. My mom leans in, expecting some sweet anesthesia confession. Ebony cups her hands around my mom's ear like she's about to share a deep secret. And then, but it's not just any burp. It's the loudest, longest, most obnoxious burp I've ever heard. And somehow in the middle of This massive belch, Ebony manages to say, I hate you. So what my mom hears directly in her ear is burp. I hate you. My mom jumps back like she's been attacked. What? Ebony starts giggling hysterically. I got you. I got you. So good. Ebony. Did you just burp I hate you in my ear? Maybe. Did it work? I'm trying not to laugh because my mom looks horrified. Ebony, that's my mom. I know she's great. I love her. That's why I gave her my special burp. My mom is still processing. Your special burp? Yeah, it's how I show affection. Jake gets them all the time. That's that's how you show affection. Ebony nods enthusiastically. The louder the burp, the more I love you. And that was a really loud burp. My mom looks at me. Jake, is this true? I'm bright red. Ebony has a very a unique way of expressing herself. Ebony interrupts Mrs. Simon. Wanna hear my impression of a dying whale? Ebony? No, but Ebony is already making horrible groaning sounds. Oh, the nurse comes running in. Is everything okay? Ebony waves at her. Hi, I'm practicing whale sounds. Ebony starts making clicking sound. Click, click, click. I'm talking to dolphins, my mom whispers to me. Is she always like this? Only when she's heavily medicated. Ebony overhears Mrs. Simon. Did Jake tell you about the time I accidentally called his dad daddy at dinner? Ebony, what? It was funny. Your dad turned So red, my mom is trying not to laugh. You called my husband daddy. Yeah. And then I asked him if he wanted to adopt me. Ebony, can we not tell my mom every embarrassing story right now? But I have so many good ones. Like time you cried watching The Notebook. Everyone cries watching The Notebook. You cried for two hours and then you made me watch it again. My mom is definitely laughing now. Jake cried for two hours. Ebony nod. And he ate an entire pint of ice cream with his hands. His hands. He said spoons were too slow for his emotional needs. I want to disappear. Ebony, you're supposed to be resting. I am resting. I'm resting my mouth by talking. The nurse checks Ebony's vitals. How are you feeling? I feel great. I just burped in Jake's mom's ear and told her I hate her, but I really love her. The nurse looks confused. You burped what? Ebony demonstrates by making another loud burping sound like that, but with words inside. My mom shakes her head. I've never experienced anything like that. Missus Simon, want me to teach you? Ebony, please don't teach my mom how to burp words. Why not? You never know when you might need to burp. Communicate. Ebony turns back to my mom. Missus Simon, I have another secret to tell you. My mom hesitates. Are you going to burp in my ear again? No. This is a real secret. Come closer. My mom cautiously leans in. Ebony whispered, I'm going to marry your son. My mom's face lights up. Really? Yeah. But don't tell him I'm going to propose to him, Ebony. That's not how proposals usually work. Why not? I'm a modern woman. I can post my potato boyfriend. Potato boyfriend. Ebony looks at me lovingly. Yeah, he's my beautiful potato. My mom is crying from laughing. Ebony, you're delightful. Thank you. That's why I gave you my best burp. The anesthesia starts wearing off and Ebony gets sleepy. Mrs. Simon, will you visit me when I'm not high on drugs? Of course, sweetie. Good. Next time I'll teach you my burping alphabet.

My wife said, stop trying to be romantic. It's pathetic. So I put a stop to our fake marriage. We've been married for five years and I thought I was being the perfect husband. I spent three hours cooking her favorite meal for our anniversary, set up candles, even dug out that playlist from our first date. When she walked through the door with her sister and best friend, she took one look at the setup, rolled her eyes and said loud enough for everyone to hear, stop trying to be romantic. It's pathetic. You look desperate. Then she turned to her friends. This is exactly what I was telling you about. He does this needy stuff constantly. The room went dead silent. Her sister looked uncomfortable. Her best friend stared at the floor. I stood there holding wine, watching my wife destroy our marriage with one sentence. I set the wine down, looked her straight in the eye and said, you know what, you're absolutely right. She expected me to apologize, to scramble. Instead, I started blowing out the candles. What are you doing? She asked, losing that confident edge. Stopping, I replied, gathering the flowers. Romance is pathetic when it's one sided. So I'm done being pathetic. I tossed the flowers in the trash and ordered pizza. We can eat like roommates from now on, pepperoni or cheese. That night she tried damage control, talking about bad days, overreacting. But something had shifted in me. I heard you. Perfectly, I told her. Message received. No more romantic gestures, no more pathetic behavior. She laughed it off. Maybe we both need to be more realistic about what marriage actually is. Those words would haunt her the next morning. I didn't bring her coffee in bed like I had every weekend for five years. When she came downstairs expecting her usual cup, I was finishing mine. Coffee's in the kitchen, I said. Without looking, I saw our marriage clearly for the first time. I was the one planning date nights she'd complain about. I was the one remembering anniversaries. I was the one keeping romance alive. When I stopped being romantic, I stopped with everything unnecessary. No more good morning kisses, no more asking about her day. No more caring where she went. By day 10, the cracks show. Are you going to ask me about my presentation? She said, clearly fishing. Do you want to tell me about it? Well, it went well, she said, waiting for follow up questions that never came. Good for you. I went back to my phone. She stood there for a full minute waiting for me to engage. When it became clear I wasn't playing that role anymore, she left without another word. Three weeks in, she was losing her mind. She mentioned male co workers talk about her ex reaching out, brought up how attentive other husbands were. Each comment was fishing for jealousy. Any sign I still cared. My response was Always. That's interesting. Then I'd return to whatever I was doing. I'd started hitting the gym, reading books, learn in guitar, something she'd always dismissed as a waste of time. One month in, she cracked. She was waiting at the kitchen table when I got home. Papers spread everywhere. We need to talk. You're punishing me because your feelings got hurt. My feelings got hurt. I repeated, you humiliated me in front of your friends. Called five years of romantic gesture.

Bro, why is the weekend only two days? Like, who decided that was enough? Two days? That's not a break, that's a prank. Like, I touch my bed on Friday, and the next thing I know, the alarms ringing and it's Monday morning. And honestly, who even invented the seven day week? Like, what if there's actually supposed to be 10 or 18 days and we all just got scammed? And why is the ratio five days of pain to two days of peace? That's like ordering a pizza and only getting two slices. Because here's the thing. The weekend is not even a real weekend. Friday night is gone in a blink, Saturday doesn't even exist. It's more like catch up on chores day, and Sunday is finish all the homework you got day. Like, why do we even get homework? Is the weekend not supposed to be the week's end? Am I not supposed to rest? Meanwhile, school takes five whole days. Five. Imagine working five shifts at a job you never applied for. And the pay. See you again on Monday. Like, bro, at least jobs give you money. School gives you stress, exams, annoying teachers, and fire drills at 8:00am when it's freezing outside. Honestly, I wish we could flip it. Two days of school, five days of weekend. That's balance. That's peace. Until then, I'll be sitting in class every Monday wondering if dropping out is a spiritual call. No.

A man at the art gallery told me I couldn't possibly understand the painting in front of us. I painted it. I was standing in front of my largest piece at the gallery opening, champagne in hand, when a man in an expensive suit approached and started explaining my own painting to me. He had no idea I was the artist because the placard said Riley Turner, who he clearly assumed was a man since he kept talking about his brilliant technique. This guy Robert looked me up and down and said, you seem young to be at an opening like this. Let me guess, looking for a rich boyfriend? Smart girl. Lots of wealthy men here. He gestured at my painting like he owned it. See, what Riley is doing here requires years of training to appreciate. You probably just think the colors are pretty. The average woman just sees decoration. I took a sip of champagne and said, interest in perspective, which I guess he took as encouragement. Robert moved closer to the painting, physically stepping in front of me, and continued his lecture. A Girl Like You probably thinks this is just nice to look at, but there's actual intelligence behind it. The artist is obviously a man because women simply don't have this kind of technical mastery. Female painters do. Flowers and feelings. This has real intellectual depth. It's biological, really. Men are just more capable of this level of abstraction. When I mentioned I was Familiar with the artist's work. Robert laughed and patted my shoulder. Following him on Instagram to look at the pretty pictures doesn't count as being familiar with art, sweetheart. You probably think you're cultured because you went to that Van Gogh light show. Real knowledge comes from decades of study, not whatever you Learned from TikTok. Robert decided to test me. Rapid firing questions. Who's Basquiat? What's Kiara Scuro? Name three Renaissance painters besides Da Vinci. When I started to answer, he cut me off. Wrong. See this? This is why galleries shouldn't have open events. You probably googled some terms before coming here to impress men, but Riley here is working in a tradition you couldn't possibly understand without a proper education. Not community college, sweetie. Real universities. He returned to my painting, now explaining it louder to draw a crowd. What Riley has achieved here would cost probably 100,000 in education to even the materials alone cost more than you'd make in a month at whatever retail job you have. He looked at my outfit with disgust. Target clearance rack, right? Someone who shops there couldn't possibly grasp the investment in this piece. He probably spent more on one brush than your entire outfit. When I suggested the artist might be self taught, Robert sneered at me. Is that how you Learned about art? Painting parties? Robert grabbed my wrist, only to another angle, his grip too tight. You're too stupid to even stand in the right spot. Riley intended for this to be viewed from exactly here. Your ignorance is actually disrespectful to his work. He kept his hand on my wrist while explaining, though. Honestly, explaining this to you is like teaching calculus to a toddler. You lack the basic foundation to understand any of it. He noticed me trying to pull away and

Your parent, their own worst enemy. My mom thought men were the cause of all evil. Ever since dad left us when I was 7. But that was years ago now. At 13, I had to wear this hideous shirt to school that said no boyfriends in three pink letters. She installed tracking apps, called during every free period, and even put a ring camera pointing at my bedroom window. But a small part of me understood why she was such a helicopter parent. We lived in a sketchy neighborhood. The first time I got cat called was on my eighth birthday. I was wearing a tutu skirt and with no man walking with us to protect us. We both got harassed by men all the time. So I could kind of see why she hated the male species so much. But here's the thing. All her rules didn't stop the harassment. They just made me an easier target. A girl walking alone, obviously without a boyfriend, practically wearing a sign that said vulnerable. That's when I met him. This guy from my chemistry class who noticed me speed walking past the bad corner one day, keys between my fingers, like mom taught me. Hey! He called out, you okay? I kept walking. Stranger danger and all that, but he persisted. I lived two blocks over. We could walk together. Mom's voice echoed in my head. That's how it starts. So I said no, practically ran away. But I noticed Him after that? Always seemed to be around when I was walking home. This went on for weeks. Until the day everything changed. One day, three guys started following me. My heart hammered as I fumbled for my phone. Then chemistry boy appeared. Just walked right up and put his arm around me. Hey, babe. Sorry I'm late. The guys backed off. Immediately. After they left, he dropped his arm. You good? When I nodded, he said something that made my skin prickle. I don't like you walking alone. Sweet or possessive? I couldn't tell. But either way, I was more scared of those three guys than him. So when he offered again, I finally said yes. Walks became a secret thing. Chemistry boy knew my whole schedule. Always texted home safe if he couldn't walk with me. Started teaching me self defense moves in the park. His hands adjusting my stance, showing me how to break a grip. Every girl should know this stuff, he said. But Mom's words never left my mind. Predators like to establish control. He'd appear at weird times. Just happened to be in the area. Sure. Once I joked about him following me, and his face went serious. I noticed things like that car that's been parked outside your house. I could have run then. Instead, I kept meeting him. Mom almost caught us once. I was in the middle of showing him where I lived. But I know when my mom's car turned The corner early. He practically dove behind a dumpster. My heart pounded as mom pulled up. Who are you talking to? Nobody. Just on the phone. I thought I was being so clever, sneaking around her rules. Turns out someone else was sneaking around, too, because a few days later, our neighbor, Mrs. Doyle, got robbed in broad daylight by someone who knew exactly when she'd be alone. The cop said mom went nuclear. It's always someone they trusted, someone who Learned their routine. She stared at me hard. You haven't been talking to any boys, right? I lied through my teeth while my phone buzzed. Another home safe text. Mystery Boy texted a lot. Like, a lot. Always asking where I was, who I was with. Once I didn't respond for an hour, and he showed up at the library looking panicked. Just worried, he said. Well, three weeks and two more neighborhood break ins later, I decided having him around was better than being alone. On days when my mom worked later, he'd sit in my closet doing homework while I kept watch. This is insane. Yeah, no kidding. Everything came crashing down on a Thursday. Mom came home early with a migraine. I barely got him in the closet before she walked in. Just gonna lie down, she said, heading to her room. He was trapped. My phone lit up with his text. Still in here? No sheet, Sherlock. That's when I heard it. Glass breaking downstairs. My whole body went ice cold. Mom appeared in my doorway, face white. Did you hear that? We froze as footsteps creaked on the stairs. Heavy, deliberate. Mom's eyes went wide. She mouth 9 1 1, but her phone was downstairs in her purse. Mine was dead. The foot steps got closer. My 4 eleven. Mom pushed me behind her, grabbing my field hockey stick. The door swung open. A man in a ski mask stood there, knife glinting. Mom swung the stick, but he caught it, yanked it away, shoved her heart into the wall. I screamed. The closet door exploded open. Chemistry boy launched himself at the intruder using those same moves he taught me. They crashed into the hallway. Call 9 1 1! He yelled.

Stranger danger and all that. But he persisted. I live two blocks over. We could walk together. Mom's voice echoed in my head. That's how it starts. So I said no, practically ran away. But I noticed Him after that always seemed to be around when I was walking home. This went on for weeks until the day everything changed. One day, three guys started following me. My heart hammered as I fumbled for my phone. Then chemistry boy appeared. Just walked right up and put his arm around me. Hey, babe, sorry I'm late. The guys backed off immediately after they left. He dropped his arm. You good? When I nodded, he said something that made my skin prickle. I don't like you walking alone. Sweet or possessive? I couldn't tell. But either way, I was more scared of those three guys than him. So when he offered again, I finally said yes. Walks became a secret thing. Chemistry boy knew my whole schedule, always texted home safe if he couldn't walk with me. Started teaching me self defense moves in the park. His hands adjusting my stance, showing me how to break a grip. Every girl should know this stuff, he said. But Mom's words never left my mind. Predators like to establish control. He'd appear at weird times. Just happened to be in the area. Sure. Once I joked about him following me and his face went serious. I noticed things like that car that's been parked outside your house. I could have run then. Instead, I kept meeting him. Mom almost caught us once. I was in the middle of showing him where I lived. But I know when my mom's car turned The corner early. He practically dove behind a dumpster. My heart pounded as mom pulled up. Who are you talking to? Nobody. Just on the phone. I thought I was being so clever, sneaking around her rules. Turns out someone else was sneaking around too, because a few days later, our neighbor, Mrs. Doyle, got robbed in broad daylight by someone who knew exactly when she'd be alone. The cop said mom went nuclear. It's always someone they trusted, someone who Learned their routine. She stared at me hard. You haven't been talking to any boys, right? I lied through my teeth while my phone buzzed. Another home safe text. Mystery boy texted a lot. Like a lot. Always asking where I was, who I was with. Once I didn't respond for an hour and he showed up at the library looking panicked, just worried. He said, well, 3 weeks and two more neighborhood break ins later, I decided having him around was better than being alone. On days when my mom worked later, he'd sit in my closet doing homework while I kept watch. This is insane. Yeah, no kidding. Everything came crashing down on a Thursday. Mom came home early with a migraine. I barely got him in the closet before she walked in. Just gonna lie down, she said. Heading to her room. He was trapped. My phone lit up with his text, still in here. No sheet, Sherlock. That's when I heard it. Glass breaking downstairs. My whole body went ice cold. Mom appeared in my doorway, face white. Did you hear that? We froze as footsteps creaked on the stairs, heavy, deliberate. Mom's eyes went wide. She mouth 9, 1, 1. But her phone was downstairs in her purse. Mine was dead. The foot steps got closer. My 4, 11. Mom pushed me behind her, grabbing my field hockey stick. The door swung open. A man in a ski mask stood there, knife glinting. Mom swung the stick, but he caught it, yanked it away, shoved her heart into the wall. I screamed. The closet door exploded open. Chemistry boy launched himself at the intruder using those same moves he taught me. They crashed into the hallway. Call 9, 1, 1, he yelled.

Parents who have adopted a older child, 5 and up. How has it gone for you? When my wife Rachel and I adopted Devon at six years old, they told us she had mild trust issues. What they didn't tell us was that she'd been returned by three families already. Devon showed up at our house with one tiny suitcase and a backpack that first night. I watched her through the doorway as she carefully laid out all her clothes on the bed. She folded each piece perfectly, put it back in the suitcase, and zipped it up. Then she slept on top of the covers, fully dressed. I thought maybe she was just nervous, but weeks went by, and that suitcase never got unpacked. We take out one outfit each morning, wear it all day, then fold it back up at night. Her closet stayed completely empty. Rachel tried everything. New sheets with unicorns on them, a night light shaped like a butterfly. We even let her pick out paint for her room walls. He chose white. Just plain white like before. One morning, I found her in the kitchen at 5 a m. Making her own breakfast. Toast with no butter. Just dry bread. When I asked why she was up so early, she said, I didn't want to bother you guys. Sometimes people get mad when kids wake them up. That broke my heart. Rachel and I had been trying for years to have kids. We dreamed About Saturday morning pancakes and bedtime stories. But Devin acted like she was living in a hotel, not a home. The real wake up call came three months later. I got home from work and heard crying upstairs. I found Devon sitting on her bed, holding that stupid suitcase in her lap. What's wrong, sweetheart? She looked up at me with these huge brown eyes and said, I heard you and Rachel fighting last night about money. I know kids cost a lot. I can go back to Miss Janet tomorrow if you want. Miss Janet was her social worker. My throat got tight. Rachel and I had been arguing about our car payment. Nothing to do with Devon at all. Devon, we weren't fighting about you. We love having you here. She just shrugged. That's what the Johnson said, too. And the Millers. They all said I was special. Until I wasn't anymore. That night, Rachel and I sat up talking until 3 a m. We realized Devon wasn't just scared of us leaving her. She was waiting for us to leave her. She'd been through this routine before. Nice family, happy faces. Then back to foster care. When things got tough the next day, I had an idea. I went to the hardware store and bought the biggest picture frame they had, like three feet wide. Then Rachel and I spent the whole weekend taking photos. Devon at breakfast, Devon watching TV, Devon playing with our dog, Charlie. Just normal, boring family stuff. We printed out all the pictures and arranged them in the frame. Beach trips we took her on. Movie nights on the couch. Devon's first day at her new school. Even the bad pictures where someone was making a weird face. When Devon got home from school Monday, we called her into the living room.

How did your daughter react to her first period? It's 7:00am. I'm still half asleep with coffee when my daughter bust into the bathroom like the FBI. She's holding her underwear up like a bloody flag and screaming, mom, I'm leaking from the wrong end! I'm gonna die! I nearly spit coffee everywhere. I say, sweetheart, calm down. That's just your period. She freezes, squints at me and yells, you liar! I knew you made that story up few months ago. I actually explained this whole thing Saturday down. Gave her the talk, showed her pictures. She rolled her eyes and said, nice prank, mom. You really think I'm that dumb? Now she's standing here like I faked the whole biology system just to mess with her. She stomps her foot. So you mean to tell me women eat every month and just go to target like nothing happened? She's pacing, yelling, you could have stopped this! You're my mom, not my enemy! I hand her a pad. She picks it up with two fingers like it's radioactive. This is a diaper. You want me to wear a diaper to school? Kids already bully me for my Lunchables. If I sound like a Doritos bag when I walk, I'm done. She sticks it on, takes two steps. Crunch, crunch! She stops, dead serious. Perfect. Now I'm Miss Fritos. Then she whispers, wait, does dad get this, too? I almost choked on my coffee. No, baby, only girls! She screams. Figures. Men don't do anything. They just fart and watch football while we bleed like stabbed pumpkins. She comes home from school later, furious. Mom, you didn't warn me the pad sticks to your leg hair. I was in that stall fighting for my life. People thought I was wrestling a raccoon. Then she adds, and when I sneezed in math, I thought my kidney fell out. Thanks, mom. Now they call me Leaky Lindsay. That night, she's on the couch, blanket eating pad, hot Cheetos in her lap, looking like a soldier who saw combat. She points at her brother and yells, enjoy your balls, loser! My. This is literally trying to kill me. He cried into his Pop Tarts. Next morning, she tries to get out of chores. Mom, I can't clean. My uterus is in critical condition. I say, nope. She glares at me, wow, you're a woman, too? And you still betrayed me. You're basically a war criminal. At dinner, my husband's carving chicken. It's calm. Suddenly, she stands up, bangs her glass with a fork, and goes, ladies and gentlemen, I am now a woman. My uterus has joined the group chat. Please clap. My husband choked on a drumstick. My son screamed, gross! And ran upstairs. And the grand finale. She whips out a Sharpie, lifts her shirt, and across her stomach she's written in giant letters, congrats, dad! You're next! I nearly passed out laughing. My husband dropped his fork like he saw a Ghost! My son slammed his door, and my daughter, she just sat back down, grabbed mashed potatoes with her hands, and goes. Period season has officially started, bitches.

I told my mom that I'm disgusted by and ashamed of my sister. It started when my sister Chloe came home crying because her boyfriend Jake dumped her. She's 25 and I'm 17, but she always acts like she's the victim in every situation. This time was different, though. She kept saying Jake was horrible and cruel. But when I asked what happened, she got all shifty. He said he broke up with her out of nowhere and kicked her out of his apartment. But then she mentioned she still had keys to his place because she forgot to give them back. The next day, she left early in the morning and came back with this huge golden retriever. I recognized him immediately. It was Buster, Jake's dog. Love that dog more than anything. When his grandpa died last year, Buster was the only thing that helped him through it. I asked Chloe why she had Buster, and she got this weird smile on her face. She said Jake didn't deserve to keep him since he broke her heart. Then she said something that made my stomach drop. She told me she was going to take Buster to the vet tomorrow to put him down as payback for what Jake did to her. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. This dog was completely healthy and happy, just confused about being in a new place. Buster kept looking around for Jake and whining by the door. It was heartbreaking. I Told Chloe she was being insane and she couldn't just kill someone's dog because she was upset. She laughed and said Jake should have thought about that before he decided to hurt her. Then she said if I told anyone, she'd make sure I regretted it. That night I couldn't sleep. I kept thinking about Buster and how scared he must be. Around 2:00am, I heard Chloe on the phone with someone, probably making the vet appointment. I knew I had to do something. Then next morning, Chloe left for work and told mom she was taking Buster for a walk later. Mom didn't know the whole story. Chloe just said Jake asked her to watch his dog for a few days. As soon as both then were gone, I called Jake. He picked up on the first ring and sounded terrible. I told him Chloe had Buster and was planning to put him down today. He went completely silent for like 10 seconds, then started freaking out. He said he'd been looking everywhere for Buster and thought maybe he got out somehow. I told Jake to come over now while Chloe was at work. He was at our house in 15 minutes. When he saw Buster, he literally started crying. Buster went crazy with excitement, jumping all over him and licking his face. I opened the door and Jake carried his dog out to his car. Before he left, Jake told me what really happened with Chloe. She didn't Just get dumped. She cheated on him with his best friend, Marcus. When Jake found out, he broke up with her and told her to move out. She stole Buster on her way out and left Jake's spare key on the counter so he thought she was being mature about the breakup. A few hours later, Chloe came home and went straight to look for Buster. When she couldn't find him, she started screaming my name. She found me in my room and absolutely lost it. She called me a traitor and said I had no right to interfere in her business. Then mom came home and asked what all the yelling was about. Chloe told her I let some guy steal her dog. She made it sound like I just gave away her pet to a random stranger. Mom looked

What's the most savage insult you've ever heard from a child? My 6 year old nephew absolutely destroyed my sister at Thanksgiving dinner. And honestly, she deserved it. My sister Emma has always been obsessed with appearances, perfect makeup, designer clothes, constantly taking selfies. She's the type who spends two hours getting ready just to go to target. At family dinners, she'd always make these passive aggressive comments about everyone else's life choices. So we're all sitting around the table Last Thanksgiving. Emma shows up an hour late because she had to get her nails done. She's wearing this ridiculous white dress to a family dinner where we're eating gravy and cranberry sauce. Classic Emma move. She immediately starts her usual routine, comments about how Mom's stuffing has too much salt this year, mentions how Uncle Rick should probably lay off the dinner rolls, makes this big show of only eating tiny portions because she's watching her figure. Then she turns to my brother Jake, who just started community college. So Jake, still taking those little classes. When are you going to get a real degree? Jake just stared at his plate. The kids working two jobs to pay for school. Emma kept going. She asked my cousin about her starter apartment and wondered when she'd get a grown up job. She even made a comment about dad's old truck in the driveway saying it was embarrassing. The whole time my nephew Tyler was just sitting there eating his Turkey. And watching Tyler's, Jake's 6 year old son, super quiet kid, usually just plays with his food and doesn't say much during adult conversations. Emma was on a roll. She started talking about her new boyfriend's BMW and how they're looking at condos downtown, really laying it on thick about how successful she is compared to everyone else. Then she made her biggest mistake. She looked at Tyler and said, Tyler, sweetie, make sure you study hard in school so you don't end up like your daddy. Okay? The table went dead silent. Jake's face turned red. Mom literally gasped. Dad put down his fork and just stared at Emma. But Tyler. Tyler just looked up from his mashed potatoes, blinked those big innocent eyes and said in the sweetest voice ever, Aunt Emma, why?
NA

Why is it actually terrifying when you're at your friend's house and they tell their mom you're hungry? Like, great, now she thinks I pulled up to run a 5 star GTA heist on her pantry. Like the other day I'm hanging at my friend's place after school, but dude has the appetite of a hummingbird, one granola bar and he's full. And I don't wanna ask for food at his house. I want him to offer like a normal human. So I start dropping hints. A McDonald's commercial comes on and I'm like, dang, a Mcchicken would go crazy right now. Then I get up to grab a glass of water and stare into the fridge like I'm touring an art museum. I even ask, yo, do you guys ever do pizza rolls here or. Nah. He just shrugs and says, I'm not really hungry. Oh, ask about you. But then when he finally picks up on the hint, instead of having his mom make us a snack, he just leans toward the kitchen and yells, mom dog is hungry. Can you make him something? Like, bro, oh, why would you say it like that? Now she either thinks my parents don't feed me at home or I'm a big back here to clear out her fridge. Yeah, do I secretly want to inhale all the food in their house? Yes, but that's beside the point. Subscribe.

Bro, 2,025 just got way more cooked because I just realized today is September 5th. 2,025 which officially means we're 67.67% through the year. And listen, this is where shit gets weird. Mango has six letters, mustard has 7. 6 + 7 = 13. Now Kendrick Lamar. That's 13 letters. And the 13th letter in the alphabet is M. You know what M stands for? Massive. But wait, if that wasn't enough, low taper fade has 12 letters. Now add that up. 13 + 12 = 25. What year are we in? The big 25? This is massive news for the unemployed.

We talk about people who self diagnose themselves. Like, no, Emily, you do not have four different mental disorders just because you saw a TikTok that said if you breathe sometimes and also blink, you might have ADHD. Congratulations, that's called being a human. Look, I get it. Mental health awareness is hella important. It's amazing that people are talking about it more openly now. But here's the problem scrolling through hashtags at 2:00am is not the same thing as a professional evaluation. Google is not your therapist. ID Labs tests are not your psychiatrist. And that one influencer who talks about their symptoms in a story time? Definitely not a doctor. When everyone just casually slaps a label on themselves, it waters down the real struggles people actually face. Like someone living with legit OCD is out here battling life every day and then some dude is like oh my god I'm so OCD I color code my closet. No, you're not OCD. You're just organized my guy. And even with depression, just because you're feeling a little sad one week does not mean you have depression. Unless you're diagnosed, I don't wanna hear it. You're free to self pity in private, but self diagnosing is probably one of the most selfish and attention seeking things you can do. Faith out.

Why don't homeless people just try and rob a bank? Like, hear me out, if they're successful, they're instantly rich. No more sleeping under bridges. They're straight up balling. But if they fail, what happens? Jail. Which is basically free food, free bed, free shelter, free Wi Fi if you're lucky. That's literally a win win situation, bro. Worst case scenario, you end up with three meals a day and a roommate named Big Mike. Best case scenario, you're the next Elon Musk, but without the lawsuit. Honestly, I don't get why no one's speed running this strategy. It sounds more efficient than half the self improvement TikToks I see.

Bro, I just realized that red is the only color in the alphabet with the same numbers and letters and numbers. Like, think about it. R is the 18th letter in the alphabet. E is the 5th, d is the fourth. Add that up, that's 27. Now hear me out. 2 + 7 equals nine. And what month are we in right now? That's right, September, the ninth month. This is actually insane. And if you flip the 9 upside down, you get a 6. Put that next to the 7 we just had, 6, 7, same exact number we've been seeing all year. This is literally massive news for the unemployed.

Holy shit. What is wrong with September? It's only been 11 days and the world is completely off its fucking rocker. Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family. David was found with a body in his car. A Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway. And now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. The scene was so bloody and gruesome, it's insane. A Ukrainian girl gets stabbed on a train in Charlotte. She escaped a literal war, came here to be safe and still got killed because this planet has zero peace. Then D4D has a whole body in his car, like not a metaphorical one, an actual human body in a bag in his trunk. And this dude just casually performed like he didn't have a horror movie in his backseat. What the hell? And even outside all of that, Elon Musk is no longer the richest person in the world, losing his top spot to a rival tech CEO, showing how unstable everything feels right now, even at the highest levels. It's like every time I open my phone, reality speed runs. Another tragedy. Like, bro, it's been 11 days. September just started. I thought my only problem this month would be math class, but no, apparently it's Full blown world collapse. Society isn't just cooked, it's burnt to ash. Wakati Huo.

You ever just realize someone who used to be your whole world is now just someone you used to know? Like no big fall out, no drama, just slowly stop talking, stop checking in, stop being us. And you sit there wondering when it happened. Like what was the moment? What did I miss? How did we go from daily convos and inside jokes to seen and silence? And the worst part, I still care. I still see stuff and think they'd laugh at this or I wish I could tell them this, but I don't cause now it feel weird. Sad how people become strangers with memories. I can reach out, I can say something, but deep down I know if they wanted to talk to me, they would have. And I'm tired of always being the one holding the glue. So I just sit with it, act like I'm over it, pretend like losing people I never thought I'd lose is normal now. Whatever. People come and go, right? But fuck some of them. I really wanted to stay mfanyabiashara.

Why is there always that one popular girl? Like bro, she doesn't even have to try. She shows up to school with a messy bun and sweatpants and somehow people are like Omg she's serving! And don't even get me started on the way she talks. She'll say the most basic thing like I'm so tired and suddenly the whole room is laughing like she just did stand up comedy. Like if I said that, people would tell me to shut up. It's like she has this magical aura where every dumb little word she says turns into a quote for everyone's Snapchat story. I swear, she's not even a person at this point. She's a whole personality template. Everyone copies how she dresses, how she types, even the way she says. Literally. At this point she is basically running the entire school. Like it's her server and the rest of us are just background NPCs loading in.
NA

We all have that one friend who's obsessed with cars, like very obsessed. You can't even mention the word engine around him without triggering a full Ted talk. You'll be like, yo, I saw this cool car today and here he comes. What car? What model, what year? V6 or V8, turbo charged, manual or automatic bro, I don't know. It was red. He'll look at a car for 0.2 seconds and go, yeah, that's a 2012 Audi S4B 8.5 with the DSG transmission and optional Black optics package. I'm sorry how you didn't even blink and they're always judging you pull up in your normal car and they're like, front wheel drive, that's crazy. Like bro, I'm just trying to get to Tesco. You can't enjoy life around this guy. You'll see a Lamborghini drive past and go, yo, that's sick. He's like, actually that's the Hurricane Evo, not the performante fake exhaust sound mid bro, shut up, it looks cool and it goes V room. Even in traffic, he's different. You're sitting there like a normal person, bored. He's sitting there like, yo, is that an E92 M3 on the other lane that in line six sings bro, I swear he's gonna propose to an engine one day and don't even ask him for car advice. He'll be like, yeah bro, just get a 2007 BMW 3:35. I trust me. Reliable, fun, daily driver. That thing breaks down if the weather sneezes. Then he acts shocked when your Engine explodes after a week. Did you warm it up properly? No, I turned it on. It's a car, not a baby. Like bro chill. Not everything is a race. I just need something that gets me from point a to point B without catching fire. But no, to him, it's all about horsepower, torque, Rev matching downshifts, the never bring lap time. Meanwhile. I just want AC and Bluetooth. Stop it. Get help. You're not Vin Diesel. You're just my mate who gets emotionally attached to vehicles.

They just found a mosquito with actual Dinosaur DNA frozen in amber. Like this is literally the plot of Jurassic Park. Did nobody watch the movie? We all saw how that went down. And you know, some scientists right now is rubbing his hands together like, hey, hey, let's break back a t. Rex. No, put that bug back in the ice where you found it, bro. If they make a real life Jurassic Park, it's over. We can't even handle regular animals. People out here getting chased by geese and you think we're ready for velociraptors? Imagine walking your dog and a raptor just hops out the bushes like, yo, what's for dinner? And you know, some rich dudes go, I pay $10,000 to pet a baby triceratops then cry when it eats his car. We already got mutant wasps, the plague and now dinosaurs, 2,025. Really speed running the apocalypse. Somebody lock that mosquito back up before it hatches. The boss fight of humanity.

Have you ever failed a test so badly that your teacher started asking about your personal life? Because one time I got a 13% on a Spanish test. Yes, 13. And my teacher goes, kitty rants, can you stay after class today? And I'm thinking, oh, no. She's furious. But instead she just looks at me like she's about to break the news that a family member passed away. And she says, Kitty rants, is everything okay at home? I'm like, yeah, why? She says, well, you've really been struggling in class lately. God, that has nothing to do with what's going on at home. I just don't speak Spanish. Comprendo espanol. But it gets even better. She goes, well, you also look really tired in class. You getting enough sleep? No. School starts at 7:50 in the morning. Of course, I'm not getting enough sleep. Then she tells me she can see the bags under my eyes. And I'm like, okay, now you're just roasting me because I always have these. That's just how I look. Trust me, I would love to have an excuse for why I failed, but I just don't speak Spanish. I barely even speak English.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket, just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight. But by 12:30, half of them are knocked out, drooling, and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation, why? Ten people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone sneaking chips at 4:00am and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part, parents roll in. Like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.

How did you trick your entire high school? Our cafeteria had this weird echo problem in the back corner where the ceiling tiles were loose. If you whispered there during lunch, it would amplify and carry across the entire room like a ghost voice. I discovered this by accident when I was hiding back there, eating alone, complaining under my breath about Mister Rodriguez's impossible math test. Suddenly, half the cafeteria turned around looking confused. That's when the idea hit me. I started small, whispering random stuff during lunch to test the range. Someone left their car lights on or free pizza in the gym, just enough to watch heads turn and people look around confused. The acoustics were perfect. My voice would bounce off the loose tiles, get amplified by the weird ceiling cavity, then float across the room like some supernatural announce. It sounded nothing like my normal voice, more like a distant radio transmission or a voice from another dimension. But then I overheard the drama that would change everything. Jessica Chen was bragging to her friends about how she'd been anonymously reporting kids to administration for vaping. I've gotten like 12 people suspended, he laughed. They have no idea it's me. I just sent anonymous tips to Principal Walsh's email. She was proud of it, genuinely proud of ruining people's lives for a few extra points on her college applications. Perfect. Target acquired. The next day during lunch, I positioned myself in the Echo corner. I Waited until Jessica was surrounded by her usual crowd, then whispered just loud enough. Jessica Chen is the vaping snitch, the whisper.

Guys, I'm in a genuine dilemma right now. School starts in two days for me and my sleep schedule is absolutely cooked. Like fam, I'm waking up at a time where the last period ends, man. How the hell are you supposed to make me wake up at 5:30, bro? Who the fuck do you think I am? And guys, I've really been trying to get my sleep schedule in check. I've been popping melatonin gummies like they were fruit snacks, man, and they haven't done shit. And guys, when I mean that, I've tried literally every single tactic I could. I mean that shit. I set 4 alarms. I slept through every single one. I was so desperate I asked my stepdad, hey, when you're getting ready for work, wake me up too. This dude really told me that. My stupid ass woke up, shook his head, and then fell back asleep. Who the fuck does that? And the crazy thing about it too is that I don't even remember any of these things happening, and all I remember is waking up at 2 p. M. With one sock on my right foot. Like, what the hell just happened? And what makes this shit even worse is that I have to open up Snapchat and Instagram. I gotta see these chocolate at my school talking about some bullshit. Like guys, I'm actually excited to start school again. And who's in my class? Shut the fuck up talking about I Miss school so much. How you already pre glazing the teachers? You haven't even met him yet. Man. Can't wait to get back into academia and pursue my academic prowess. Like god damn bro zip it up when you're done. Like guys, I'm low key realizing now that I haven't improved a single bit through this summer. My fits didn't get tougher, I didn't get a glow up, I didn't really lose weight. Fam, I'm the exact same motherfucker who they saw get sent to OAC. Nothing changed about me. I actually can't do this anymore man. There's no way. School starting in two days bro. I'm so fucked. Baked, deep fried, literally everything under the sun that I could be right now. I am and there's no way I'm gonna make it on school on time bro. I genuinely think there's something wrong with me man cause I'm going to bed when school starts and waking up when school ends. Man this has to be some sort of joke. It's like my body is telling me ha fuck you man. Figure it out. Like god damn man I thought we were a team so I don't know what I'm gonna do. I'm just gonna have to try and figure it out. So uh. Yeah. But yeah guys she's on my discord. Link is in my bio so follow me on YouTube. Link is in my bio as well.

Nobody should be celebrating Charlie Kirk's death, man. I gotta say this because it's been sitting on my chest. Nobody, and I mean nobody, should be celebrating Charlie Kirk's death. And before anybody gets mad at me, hear me out. I don't care if you hated what he stood for. I don't care if you never agreed with a single thing that came out of his mouth. There's a difference between disagreeing with someone and actually cheering when they're gone. Like, do you realize how weird that is? A man just lost his life, and the first instinct some people have is to make jokes, memes, clap, emojis, little he deserved it comments, bro. That's not activism. That's not standing for what you believe in. That's just heartless. And let's not forget, behind all the politics, behind all the headlines, there's a real family sitting there grieving. There's a wife who just lost her husband. There's kids who just lost their dad. Imagine being them, scrolling online and seeing people laugh about it. That doesn't make you powerful. It doesn't make you woke. It makes you cold. Here's the bigger picture. When you start normalizing this energy, when you start clapping every time somebody you don't like goes down, you're not actually winning anything. You're just feeding into the same negativity you claim to be against. You're lowering the bar of empathy until there's nothing left. And what happens then? Everyone's just waiting for the next tragedy to entertain them. That's not society. That's just chaos. You can hate his views, you can call out his words, you can spend your whole life disagreeing with the man. That's fine. That's human. But death is bigger than politics. Death is bigger than arguments. And if we really want the world to be a better place, maybe it starts with not cheering when someone's gone. So, yeah, nobody should be celebrating Charlie Kirk's death. You don't gotta like him, but at least respect life. Because if you lose that, if you can't even respect the finality of death, then, honestly, what does that say about you?

My wife said don't lecture my kids, get your own. When I tried to correct my stepdaughter, I just smiled and said, alright. I'm Brandon, 38 and married to Samantha for three years. She has twin 12 year olds from her first marriage, Charlotte and Aiden. Their dad sends birthday cards twice a year if we're lucky. Last Tuesday, I caught Charlotte stealing 20 bucks from Samantha's purse. When I confronted her, she rolled her eyes and said, you're not my real dad. You can't tell me what to do. I calmly told Samantha what happened. Instead of addressing the theft, she got defensive. Don't lecture my kids about money. If you want a parent so badly, get your own children. That's dumb. But I just smiled and said, alright. See, what Samantha didn't know was that I've been covering their car insurance, phone bills and school supplies for months. While she struggled with debt, I'd also been quietly setting aside college funds for both kids, $400 a month each in the savings accounts they didn't even know existed. The next morning, I canceled everything. Car insurance, gone. Phone plan, terminated. The college accounts I'd open, closed and transferred to my personal savings. I also stopped buying groceries. No more weekly 200 dollar trips to keep the pantry stocked. No more paying for their Netflix, Spotify or Charlotte's dance classes that cost me $150 a month. Aiden soccer registration fees, not my problem anymore. I even canceled the family gym. Membership and stopped paying for their school lunches. Every subscription, every monthly payment, every little expense I've been quietly handling, all of it gone. When Charlotte's phone got shut off at school and she couldn't call her friends, she came home furious. Why isn't my phone working? Ask your mom, I said, not looking up from my laptop. Aiden couldn't get picked up from soccer practice because the car insurance had lapsed and Samantha's registration was expired. She had to leave work early, costing her overtime pay she desperately needed. That evening, Samantha panicked when she opened the fridge to find it nearly empty. The pantry was bare except for some stale crackers and a can of beans. Where's all the food? What happened to everything? She demanded, hands shaking as she looked at the empty shelf.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included. Never prioritize. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends. I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person, while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.
NA

The popular girls at school bullied me for my Roblox channel, so I got revenge. My life has been a living hell since they found my channel and it's getting worse every day, all because of one group of girls. Like it started with hate comments and putting pictures in my locker, but the final straw was when they came into school and handed me a T-shirt of my channel asking if I could sign it since I'm so famous. And bro, her friends acted like this was the funniest thing they'd ever seen. But I wasn't gonna just let this slide now. So I did some digging and found all their social media channels and saw that they're actually trying to blow up on TikTok themselves, just not with much success. So since they want to be famous, I'll make them famous by exposing everything they said all in this video, then sending it to their parents, future college, and blowing this video up from millions to see. Help boost the video by subscribing.

Why is there always that one person who's never seen without a vape? Like, bro, do you even breathe air? They hit that thing like it's their life support. One puff every five seconds. You'll be mid conversation and suddenly cloud of blueberry, Vanilla Ice blast hits your face like a smoke machine at a concert. And it's always the wildest flavors too. Dragon blood, watermelon, cotton candy, explosion or some nonsense. I'm like, bro, that's not a snack. That's battery powered diabetes. And what kills me is they always say I'm not addicted though, while their vape is literally on a lanyard like a damn necklace. Take one deep breath without it. I dare you. Their lungs probably smell like a Yankee Candle store at this point. They don't even exhale. They just exist in mist.

What's the biggest plot twist of your life? Me and my older brother Nate were best friends growing up. He was everything I wanted to be, tough, protective, always getting me out of trouble. When I messed up, when I broke Mrs. Wilson's window playing baseball, Nate took the blame and got grounded for two weeks. When I failed my math test, spent hours helping me study for the retake. We shared everything, our tiny bedroom, video games, even a fake ID when we got to college, our parents died in a car crash when I was 15. The whole world felt like it was ending. But Nate stepped up immediately. He was only 22, barely an adult himself, but he became my legal guardian without hesitation. He dropped out of his senior year, got two jobs, working at a warehouse during the day and cleaning offices at night. I never heard him complain once. He'd come home exhausted, covered in sweat and dust, but still help me with homework. When other kids got allowances, Nate made sure I had lunch money. When I wanted new sneakers, he worked overtime to get them. He never made me feel like a burden, even though I knew I was draining every penny he earned. I graduated high school with decent grades and got into State College. Nate was so proud. He cried at my graduation, said our parents would have been proud, too. He kept working those same two jobs to pay my Tuition, living off ramen noodles and hope. I promised him someday I'd pay him back for everything. Four years later, I landed a good job at an accounting firm, finally making real money. First thing I did was try to give Nate cash, but he refused, said seeing me succeed was payment enough. That's just how he was, never wanted anything for himself. Last Thanksgiving, I brought my fiance, Emma, home to meet him. She'd heard all my stories about my amazing big brother who raised me. They got along great, laughing at old photos, Nate telling embarrassing stories about when I was little. Everything felt perfect. Later that night, after Emma went to bed, Nate asked me to sit down. He looked nervous, fidgeting with his coffee cup like he used to do when we were kids. And he had something serious to tell me.

When I came back from work, I saw my six year old daughter standing outside freezing in the snow. I slammed on the brakes and jumped out of my car. Nora, baby, what are you doing out here? She was shivering violently and just her school clothes, no coat, tears frozen on her little cheeks. Daddy locked me out, he said. I can't come back until you get home from work. My heart dropped. It was nine PM on a Friday. Jonathan knew I always worked late on Fridays. This wasn't an accident. How long have you been out here since you left this morning, she whispered. I scooped her up feeling how ice cold her little body was and carried her toward our front door. It was locked. I used my key, Fury building with every step. I found Jonathan exactly where I expected, sprawled on the couch in his boxers and T-shirt, controller in hand, playing call of duty. The heat was cranked up to 75 degrees. Empty beer cans littered the coffee table. Why was our daughter outside for 12 hours? I tried to keep my voice calm. He didn't even pause his game. She spilled grape juice on my new controller this morning. I told her actions have consequences. I stared at him in disbelief. She's 6 years old, Jonathan. She spilled juice accidentally and you left her outside to freeze? Maybe next time she'll be more careful around my stuff. That's when I noticed Nora's Pink backpack sitting by the front door. It was stuffed, bulging at the seams. Her favorite stuffed bunny was sticking out the top. What's this? I pointed at the bag. Jonathan finally paused his game and turned to look at me. There was something cold in his eyes I never seen before. I've been doing a lot of thinking today. While she was outside, he said slowly, this whole family thing isn't working out for me, nor is too much work, too expensive, too loud. And honestly, I never wanted kids in the first place. The room started spinning. What are you talking about? I'm talking about you taking her and leaving tonight. I already had the locks changed while you were at work. You just got lucky I hadn't switched them out yet. I felt like I was in a nightmare. You're abandoning your own daughter. Nora was still clinging to me, her wet clothes soaking through my work blazer. She was listening to every word, her big brown eyes darting between us. Here's the thing. Jonathan stood up, stretching like this was all perfectly normal. She's not really mine anyway. I mean, yeah, biologically, whatever, but I never signed up for this dad life. You can have her. The casual cruelty in his voice made me sick. This was the man I've been married to for eight years, the man who used to read Nora bedtime stories. Jonathan, she's your daughter. You can't just watch me. He picked Up phone. I already talked to my buddy Steven, who's a lawyer. Apparently, if I just voluntarily give up my parental rights, I don't have to pay child support either. Win, win. My hands started shaking, but not from fear, from rage. I pulled out my phone and speed dialed a number I'd hoped I'd never have to use. Hi, Christine. It's Caroline. Remember that emergency custody documentation we discussed six months ago? File everything tonight. Jonathan's controller slipped from his hands. What are you doing? What you should have expected when you decided to mess with my.

My school is forcing me to delete my YouTube channel. After the video exposing my bullies went viral, my principal randomly called me into his office saying he wanted to talk. So I'm thinking, finally, those girls are about to get punished for the public humiliation they caused me. But I couldn't have been more wrong. I walk in the room and see the two girls already sitting there with my video playing on the principal's laptop. And I'm just standing there getting ready for the pure satisfaction of watching their punishment unfold. But instead, he suddenly turns to me, slams his hand on his desk, and goes, do you know how much harassment you've caused for these girls, bro? These girls bullied me for days, but you're telling me I'm the one getting punished for it? And if that wasn't bad enough, that's when he gave me the decision. You need to either stop posting and delete these hateful videos, or I'll have no choice but to suspend you. If I should keep posting. Subscribe, please.
