My parents demanded I should do 50% of all chores, but they didn't expect that to backfire on them. We're done being your servants, mom announced, slapping a contract on the kitchen table I'd scrubbed an hour ago. This says that you will do exactly 50% of all household chores. Sign it. She started recording on her phone while dad stood behind her, arms crossed. We're exhausted from carrying you. The irony was incredible. I been doing way more than 50% of everything for two years. While they couldn't even tell you where we kept the laundry detergent. Mom hadn't cooked since 2022. Dad hadn't touched a vacuum in forever. Yet they genuinely believe they were doing most of the housework. 50% or find somewhere else to live, dad added, wearing the shirt I'd ironed that morning. I looked at the contract, then at their smug faces, then I signed it with a smile. You're absolutely right, 50% starting tomorrow. I promise I'll never do more than my exact share again. They actually high five each other like they'd just won a free slave in the lottery, realising their problems were about to skyrocket. The next morning, mom was on the phone with her sister at 6:00am, bragging about their breakthrough in parenting. We finally taught him responsibility, she gloated. Kids these days need firm boundaries, dad chimed in from the bathroom. Should have done this years ago. Watch how smooth everything runs now that he knows we mean business. They moved through their morning routine with the confidence of people who never had to think about clean clothes magically appearing in their closets or lunches mysteriously packing themselves. That's when I decided to follow exactly what the contract said. Twenty minutes later, I started the laundry and pulled my clothes out mid cycle, leaving the machine full of soapy water. Dad discovered his work shirts floating in cold gray water at 7:00am, his confident whistling dying mid note as he started screaming from the laundry room. He he missed his critical client meeting trying to dry a shirt with Mom's hair dryer still damp, patches visible during his afternoon presentation. Mom fared no better. She'd assumed her presentation outfit would be clean as always, only to find it buried under a week of their dirty clothes. She did her zoom presentation to corporate in a wrinkled gym shirt, her credibility evaporating as quickly as her promotion chances. By Wednesday, the house reeked, taking out exactly one trash bag, mine, leaving theirs to ferment in the summer heat. When Mom's book club arrived, I watched from my spotless half of the living room as her best friend's face contorted at the smell. We're doing exactly fifty. Fifty now, I explained cheerfully, showing them Mom's recorded contract. She was very insistent about fairness. The women exchanged glances before suddenly remembering other commitments. Mom's smile cracked like old paint. Real collapse came Friday when Dad's boss arrived for dinner. I'd vacuumed exactly Half of each room, leaving a perfect line down the middle like a bizarre art installation. The dining table was set only on my side, where I sat eating takeout while dad frantically tried to explain why half their home looked abandoned. Where's the food? Dad hissed in the kitchen. I only bought my half of groceries. Cooking for others would exceed my share, I called out loud enough for his boss to hear. The man left after 15 minutes muttering about family issues. When they realized they'd messed up, they attempted gaslighting me into going back to how things were. You're being deliberately difficult, mom accused during another family meeting. This isn't what we meant, and you know it. I pulled out my phone, playing back her video from the first meeting. You said, and I quote, exactly 50% of all household chores. No more free rides. I have spreadsheets showing I'm doing precisely 50%. Dad tried a different angle. You're supposed to be mature enough to understand what we really meant. Oh, so you meant I should read your minds instead of following the written contract you made me sign. They went silent, awkwardly avoiding my eyes. They couldn't exactly scold me about doing exactly what they wanted me to do, but their friends started joking about the 50% house. At social gatherings, they cracked. Please just go back to how things were before, mom begged. We didn't realize you were doing so much, dad nodded frantically. We'll Rip up the contract. Just please clean the bathroom properly. My boss is coming for dinner tomorrow. I leaned back in my chair, savoring the moment. Actually, I'm really enjoying this new system. It's given me so much more time for studying, and my grades have never been better. Plus, you were right, 50% is much fairer than what I was doing before. The panic in their eyes was palpable.
NA

When did you find out everyone in your school was in danger? I was in Mr Aneta's history class when the announcement came over the intercom. Code Red. Code red. This is not a drill. Everyone froze. We practiced this 100 times. Lock the door. Turn off the lights. Hide in the corner. Mr Grenada immediately jumped up and reached for the door lock. Then Vice Principal Medina's voice boomed through the speaker. False alarm, everyone. Some pranksters called in a fake threat. Continue with your lessons. Do not lock your doors. I repeat, do not initiate lockdown procedures. Mr Grenada hesitated with his hand on the lock. My friend Maddie whispered from her desk. I said, Code Red, that's the real signal. Mr Aneta looked confused. The VP says it's fake, though. Then we heard it, footsteps running down the hallway, not walking, running hard and fast like someone was being chased. Mr Medina's voice came back on. Teachers, I said, continue teaching. Any classroom that locks their door will have their teacher written up for insubordination. Mr Arneta slowly backed away from the door. He looked scared but sat back at it desk. Everyone stay calm. Let's continue with the lesson. Sweat was dripping from his forehead and nobody could focus. The running footsteps kept happening, first on our floor, then above us and back again. pulled out my phone and opened our school's parent Facebook group. My mom had posted that police were surrounding the School. They told us someone called about a weapon. She spammed my phone saying she loves me. My hands started shaking. I showed Maddie the post. Her face went white. She raised her hand. Mr Aneta, my mom says the police are outside. Mr Aneta walked to the window and peeked through the blinds. He gasped loudly. There were six police cars in the parking lot. Mr Medina came on again. Students ignore any social media posts. This is a routine false alarm. Any student caught on their phone will receive immediate suspension. Any teacher who initiates lockdown will be terminated. I saw Mr Aneta's jaw clench. We could hear doors slamming somewhere in the building, not closing, slamming like someone was checking rooms. Then we heard something that made everyone freeze. The fire exit at the end of our hallway opened and slammed shut. Someone was on our floor. Maddie grabbed my arm so tight it hurt. The footsteps were getting closer, classroom by classroom. Mr Grenada stood up and walked toward the door again, but he stopped. He looked at us and at the door and back at us. The footsteps stopped right outside our room. That's when Pete, the quiet kid who never talked, stood up. He grabbed his desk and started dragging it toward the door. Mr Anetta, help me now. Mr Anetta snapped out of it. What are you doing? Pete didn't stop. My dad's a cop, he said. If we ever hear Code Red, We lock down no matter what anyone says, even the principal. The door knob started to turn. Everyone moved at once. Kids grabbed desks and chairs and shoved them against the door. Mr Anetta finally joined us. Lights, someone get the lights. Maddie hit the switch. We pushed everything we could find against that door. The person outside pushed hard. The door opened a crack, but hit our barricade. They put harder. Mr Medina's voice screamed through the intercom, which classroom is refusing to follow directions? You will all be expelled. But we didn't care about his threats anymore. The person outside kicked the door. The whole barricade shook. Some girls started crying. Pete pointed to the back.

Hey, have y'all been totally shook by TikTok lately? Like for real? A few days ago I tried this new feature they dropped where TikTok literally picks a song for your photo automatically. Sounds kind of cute, right? So I'm like, okay, let me just try it. I hit that little plus sign at the bottom, snapped a quick selfie, smiling and chill. No big deal. Then TikTok picks a song for me and it's Adele's Someone Like You. I was like, wait, what? I literally just woke up, was feeling cute, and TikTok's out here making it seem like I'm going through a breakup or something. So of course I had to try again. This time I took a pic of my cat just sleeping, all peaceful and cozy. Guess what song TikTok gave me? Megan, thee Stallion. Savage. Now my cat's out here being a whole bad bitch. Like what's going on TikTok? My friend tried it too. She took a pic of her breakfast, some toast and eggs, all cute and simple, and TikTok gave her unholy. At this point I'm seriously wondering if this app has psychic powers. It's not just matching songs to photos, it's like reading right through your soul. Now every morning I'm like, okay, what moods TikTok gonna give me today? I snap a pic and wait for the app to tell me how I'm feeling with a song. Y'all gotta try this. Take any pic, let TikTok pick your vibe. Then Come back and tell me what song it gave you. Because honestly, I need to know if I'm the only one getting mind read by TikTok

Eight months pregnant, I sat at dinner when my mother in law smiled and asked, are you excited to give birth in our basement? I stared in shock. What basement? I'm giving birth at the hospital. Oh, honey, Agnes said, reaching across the table to pat my hand. women have been delivering babies at home for five generations. I delivered Brent and his sisters right here in this house. My husband Brent squeezed my shoulder. Mom's delivered over 20 babies for our family. She knows what she's doing. The baby kicked hard against my ribs like it was trying to escape this conversation. We've been living in Brent's childhood home while our house underwent renovations. Not once had anyone mentioned this family tradition. I already have an OB, I said, my voice shaking. We've been planning a hospital birth. I'm high risk because of my blood pressure. Agnes waved her hand dismissively. Hospitals are where people go to die. Your own mother died giving birth in one of those places. The words hit me like a physical blow. My mother had died from complications, my birth. Brad followed me to our bedroom later that night. I was shoving clothes into my overnight bag when he grabbed my wrist. You're overreacting, he said. This is how my family does things. I'm not giving birth in some basement room with your mother playing doctor. His face hardened in a way I've never seen before. If you can't respect our traditions, Then maybe this marriage was a mistake. I froze. You're threatening divorce because I want actual medical care. He showed me our prenup clause 15. In case of divorce due to irreconcilable differences about family values, you forfeit custody rights. My legs went weak. I sank onto the bed. I had no money of my own, no family since my father died last year. Without Brent, I'd lose everything, including my baby. The next weeks became a waking nightmare. Agnes started her preparations, which included drinking foul smelling teas and attending birthing circles with other women from their community. During one session, a woman named Carol pulled me aside. My sister died during one of Agnes's home births five years ago, she whispered. They said it was God's will, but she bled out while Agnes refused to call an ambulance. My blood turned to ice that night. I searched online for anything about the Mitchell family. Three women had died during home births in this county over the past 15 years. Agnes's name was never mentioned, but the address. This were all in this neighborhood. The headache started the following week. My vision blurred and my feet swelled so badly I couldn't wear shoes, classic signs of preclampsia. When I told Agnes, she gave me more herbs and said hospital monitoring would just stress them, baby. She took my phone the next day, said I was reading too many scary stories online. Brent agreed it was for the best. I Waited until Agnes left for her weekly grocery run and snuck to the neighbor's house. I called my old colleague who worked as a labor and delivery nurse. You need to get to a hospital now, she said, after I described my symptoms. You could have a stroke or seizure. The baby could die. I can't, I sobbed. I'll lose custody if I leave. You'll lose your life if you stay. That night at dinner, I showed Brent the information she had texted. For the first time, I saw doubt cross his face. Maybe we should just get you checked, he said quietly, just to be safe. Agnes slammed her hand on the table. Absolutely not. Doubt is what kills mothers and babies. Faith is what saves them. But Brent held firm. We'll go tomorrow morning just for a quick check up. I never made it to morning. The contraction started at 2:00am, five weeks early. Brent ran for his keys, but Agnes had already taken them. She locked the doors from the inside with keys only she had. This is meant to be, she said, only as I doubled over in pain. The baby knows when it's time. Brent pounded on the doors, tried to break windows, but Agnes had prepared for this. Security bars on everything. No phones, no landline in our room. She LED me to the basement where her birthing room waited. Ancient equipment that belonged in a museum, stained sheets, the smell of old blood. Poorly masked by incense. As the contractions intensified, I heard Agnes on an old rotary phone in the corner. Yes, the policy is.
NA

Man, there is no lonelier feeling in school than when the teacher says, alright, class, pick a partner. And suddenly it's like musical chairs, but your chair disappeared. Like it's instant. People don't even wait. They already sliding across the room, locking in with their besties, acting like they rehearsed it. And me, I'm just sitting there fake smiling, pretending I'm not slowly panicking inside. You try to play it cool, looking around casually, acting like you're just taking your time. Deep down you're screaming, please, somebody make eye contact with me. And somehow everyone just knows how to avoid you. Like your whole class became trained professionals and not seeing you. It's like they went blind with precision. You shift in your seat a little, do that awkward cough like, hey, I'm still here. Nothing. Then the teacher hits you with the, oh, looks like you don't have a partner. Thanks for announcing it to the entire room, Mrs. Ava. Why not just put me under a spotlight and cue the sad violin while you're at it? And the worst part, the teacher sees it, oh, you don't have a partner. Hmm. Okay, just join that group over there, bro. That group already teamed up, planned the project, probably already gave each other nicknames and now I gotta slide in like the substitute friend. It's always the quiet group too. So now we're all just awkwardly pretending to be okay while not saying a single word at that point. I'm like, you know what, I'll work alone. I'll suffer in silence. At least I don't gotta ask someone if I can use their glue stick. And don't even get me started on when the teacher just assigns you to the one person in class you don't get along with. Now y'all gotta pretend to be civil for 5 minutes while exchanging half hearted ideas and silently judging each other's handwriting.

We all have that one friend that just never sleeps. Like I swear bro does not know what a bed is. I'll wake up at 8:00am and they're still online. Like, bro, I haven't slept yet. Like, what do you mean you haven't slept yet? I swear bro is secretly an owl because they never go to bed until it's brighter than the billboards in Times Square. It becomes genuinely impossible to make plans with them because their whole sleep schedule is comparable to Batman. Like, bro, one time I invited them to go see a movie at three PM and they look at me like I just suggested we go jump into the Grand Canyon. It genuinely gets to a point where I go weeks without seeing them because we're never awake at the same time. I swear sometimes I'll see them at school with eye bags darker than my future and they'll go, bro, I've been awake for 36 hours. Like it's some sort of flex, my brother in Christ, go to bed. And the worst part is that they'll genuinely try to act like it's normal. Like, nah, I'm built differently. No, bro, you're built wrong. You're not mysterious. You're medically concerning. I genuinely think we need to have an intervention for them because at this rate, they're gonna end up sleepwalking off a cliff.
NA

My girlfriend said, you're my boyfriend, so act like one. So I did exactly that and watched her world crumble. She watched me get down on one knee five times and said no every single time. Eight years together. I've been playing husband since year 2. Paying her car note, keeping her on my insurance, covering most of the rent while she found herself through three different careers. She had this whole routine down. Tears in her eyes, hand on her heart. Then some perfectly rehearsed excuse. We're not ready, let's wait till we're more stable. The timing isn't right. Then came proposal No. 5. And she finally showed me who she really was. I'd gone all out this time. I'm convinced myself that maybe the problem was I hadn't made it special enough. I rented out her favorite restaurants, rooftop, hung string lights everywhere, and invited all our friends and family there. The whole production cost me three months salary, but I thought it'd be worth it. When she finally said yes. My girlfriend stood there in the dress I'd bought her, surrounded by everyone we knew. And she didn't even let me finish the speech. Just shook her head with this pitying smile. Like I was a dog that wouldn't stop bringing her the same stick. Back at our apartment that night, I finally broke. Asked her straight up if she loved me. Why did she keep doing this? Her whole face changed in an instant. And the Mask came completely off. It's my choice when I accept a proposal, she said, voice ice cold. You don't get to pressure me with your timeline. You're my boyfriend, so act like one. Stop trying to be my husband when I haven't even accepted your proposal. Know your place. Know my place? After eight years of building a life together, I was supposed to know my place? Those words rewired something in my brain. Eight years of playing husband while she kept me a boyfriend status because it was convenient for her. She wanted me to act like a boyfriend. Fine. I give her exactly what she asked for. But boyfriends don't pay their girlfriends bills. Boyfriends don't share bank accounts. Boyfriends don't sacrifice their futures for someone who won't even wear their ring. I started my new boyfriend only policy the next morning while she was at her yoga class. First, I sold the ring to a dealer for 12 grand, enough to cover what I'd spent on her car this year alone. Then I called Verizon and removed her from my phone plan. By the time she got home from yoga, I changed every password and moved my money from our joint account. Didn't even notice until lunch when her phone died mid phone call. Babe, my phone's not working. She texted from her laptop, annoyed but not worried. Call Verizon. It's being weird. An hour later, they said, I'm not on the account anymore. Then the panic Started creeping in. What did you do? I responded, I'm being your boyfriend and not your husband, just like you said. She actually laughed at first, thinking it was some kind of joke. She came home that night, acting extra sweet. Made my favorite dinner and tried to cuddle on the couch. Okay, you made your point, she said, kissing my neck. I'll think about what you said. Now fix my phone. I moved to the guest bedroom instead. The next morning, she couldn't log into Netflix. Then Hulu died.

I started calling everyone in my family fat every single week without fail. Aunt Patricia watched my plate like a hawk. Sweetie, are you sure you need the mashed potatoes and the rice? Then came the clothing comments. That's a brave choice wearing horizontal stripes. You know, dark colors are more slimming. I tried everything. I asked her privately to please stop focusing on my body. I told her it hurt my feelings. I even brought articles about body positivity. She patted my hand and say she was just looking out for me because she loved me. That opened the flood gates. Patricia has a point about portion control. My cousin Jennifer chimed in at Thanksgiving. Have you tried intermittent fasting? I could send you some links. Uncle Rob began his helpful gym advice. You know, muscle burns more calories. My 12 year old nephew started asking if I really needed dessert. Even grandma, sweet grandma, started saying things like, you have such a pretty face. If only my birthday dinner last month was when they took it too far. As I reached for a second slice of my own birthday cake, the entire table collectively sucked in their breath. Aunt Diane actually moved the cake. Go away from me. We're doing this because we love you, she said. Fifteen relatives nodded an agreement. The next family dinner, I came prepared. Aunt Patricia reached for the bread and I gasped. Patricia, carbs after six? That's brave. She froze, hand midair. I kept.

Guys, y'all do not know how annoying it is to be colorblind. Like you're just chilling with your friends and then you tell them or they find out that you're colorblind. They will begin to ask the dumbest question, like, what color is my shirt? Or what color is the grass? Like, your shirt is purple. And then they say, no, it's blue. Like, bro, it isn't my fault that I didn't know that because I see purple. And then as soon as they know it, they'll tell their friends, like, bro, did you know he's color blind? And then in one second, everyone comes and asks me questions. And then there is that one time I was with a friend, we got out of the store and I see a purple bicycle with green wheels. So I say, bro, what is that combination, bro? Like purple and green? And then he says, bro, that's blue. And I say, no. And then he calls an old man and says, sir, that bicycle is blue, right? And that gentleman says, yes. And then he says, well, that guy says it's purple. Or one time I saw someone drawing with gray and I asked him, dude, why are you coloring with gray? And he says, uh, bro, it's dark green.

You ever been happy about intentionally manipulating someone? Every Thursday for three years, I told my wife Becca the same thing. I'm going to hang with the boys tonight. Be back around midnight. Truth is, I was driving to the cinema to watch movies alone because I just needed some me time. But then two months ago, my movie ended abruptly, and I came home two hours earlier than planned. When I turned onto our street, there was a black Infinity in our driveway. My heart stopped as I watched back all the footage from our doorbell camera and saw a man getting out of the car and walk. Hang up like he'd done it before. Becca opened. Before he could ring, they kissed. The kind where her hand went to his neck. My stomach dropped. I wanted to burst through that door and confront them, but I decided on the spot that that would be too kind. I need. Needed to do something else. Something that would destroy her. So I drove around until 12:30 and walked in with a story about Tony getting drunk. Becca was showering. Hey, babe. How was your night? Good. You know how it is. Then next two Thursdays, I kept my routine, but park down the street at 8:30 to watch. At the same time, the same car pulled up. I zoomed in on the ring footage, and that's when it hit me. The man was Mark. Mark, who supposedly moved to Seattle. Two years ago, my knees were shaking, but I took screenshots and sent them to my lawyer to further build my case. When I was confident enough that I had everything basically set up, I dropped the bomb. Becca was going on about her fake plans for when I left for Boys Night, when I randomly blurted out, you know who I miss? Mark. That guy and I used to have so much fun before he moved to Seattle. Her fork stopped halfway to her mouth just for a second. Yeah, Mark was great. You guys still text, though, right? Sometimes. The next morning, she woke up different, with this nervous energy. She made some phone calls behind closed doors, and since it was Thursday, during lunch, she texted, what time are you heading out tonight? She never asked before, so I knew. The comment about Mark got her. Probably 7:30. Why? Just wondering. The guys doing anything special? Same old. After work. She was cooking in full makeup. You look nice, I said. Just felt like making an effort for you to come home to. But she kept checking her phone and setting it down, then pick getting it back up at 7:15. She practically pushed me out. Don't want you to be late. Tell everyone I say hi. I drove to my regular spot down the street where I watched them, but this time, there was no car that showed up. And at 9:15, Becca's own car pulled Out. I followed her. First stop, O'malley Sports Bar, where she thought I'd be. She walked in confidently, then came out five minutes later looking confused, checking her phone, scanning the parking lot. Then she got back in her car. Her second stop, the dugout, another sports bar. Through the windows, I watched her walk the entire place, moving table to table, even checking the bathroom entrance area. She showed her phone to a waitress, who shrugged. Back to the car, more frantic phone checking. Third stop, Buffalo Wild Wings. She stayed longer this time, 15 minutes. I could see her at the bar talking to the manager, showing him something on her phone. Probably my pic. He shook his head, pointed to their mostly empty tables. Thursday wasn't exactly Prime Sports Bar night. Fourth stop, the dive bar where Tony actually used to drag us. She went straight to the bartender. I slipped in through the side door, ducked into the hallway by the bathrooms. Heard her say, every Thursday night, group of guys, probably five or six of them, loud. One of them looks like this. The bartender studied her phone. Thursday's our slowest night. I definitely remember a regular group. Sorry. She left looking frustrated, sat in her car for five minutes typing furiously. Then she drove to the A M C. Theater. I gave her a 10 minute head start, then walked in through the side entrance. She was at the concession stand talking to the Teenage manager showed her phone again. He pointed toward the theaters. She went to check each one. Open doors, scanning the sparse Thursday night crowds. I went back to my car. Twenty minutes later, she emerged, looking defeated. Sat in her car for another 10 minutes. Through her rear window, I could see her on the phone, gesturing with her free hand. Probably calling Mark. Probably saying she couldn't find me anywhere. That maybe I knew that Thursday nights might not be safe anymore. She even drove by two more bars on the way home. Quick stops, desperate checks. When I got home at my your time, she was on the couch with wine, trying to look casual, but her leg was bouncing. How was your night? Studying. Guys go. Oh, Malley's. Why? Her jaw clenched. No reason. Just curious. Was it busy? Pretty dead, actually. Who all was there? Haven't heard their names in a while. The usual.

You ever notice how sleepovers sound fun until it's actually 3:00am and nobody's acting normal anymore? Like at first we're watching movies, eating snacks, all good vibes. But the second the lights go out, chaos. Suddenly someone's laughing at nothing for 20 minutes straight. Another kid is making shadow puppets on the wall like it's a Broadway show. And there's always that one kid who forgets to bring anything. No pillow, no blanket, just vibes. He's over there sleeping on the carpet using a hoodie as a mattress. And there's the group that swears they're staying up all night. Big talk at midnight. But by 12:30, half of them are knocked out brutally and the other half are wide awake arguing if aliens are real. And the food situation, wild. You got 10 people fighting over the last slice of pizza like it's a custody battle. Someone's sneaking chips at 4:00am and the crinkle of the bag might as well be a fire alarm. When morning comes, everyone wakes up looking like they've survived a natural disaster. Hair's a mess, someone's missing a sock and the kid who slept on the floor can't walk straight anymore. Best part, parents roll in. Like, so did you guys get some rest? Yeah, sure. If by rest you mean four minutes of sleep and permanent brain damage.
NA

The popular girls at school bullied me for my Roblox channel, so I got revenge. My life has been a living hell since they found my channel, and it's getting worse every day, all because of one group of girls. Like, it started with hate comments and putting pictures in my locker, but the final straw was when they came into school and handed me a T-shirt of my channel, asking if I could sign it since I'm so famous. And, bro, her friends acted like this was the funniest thing they'd ever seen. But I wasn't gonna just let this slide now, so I did some digging and found all their social media channels and saw that they're actually trying to blow up on TikTok themselves, just not with much success. So since they wanna be famous, I'll make them famous by exposing everything they said, all in this video, then sending it to their parents, future college, and blowing this video up for millions to see. Help boost the video by subscribing.

Can we talk about how it fucking sucks to be everyone's friend but no one's favorite? I don't know if anyone else feels this, but it's like I'm never really alone, but I'm never really chosen either. I'm the one people are happy to see in the group, the one they'll talk to if no one else is around, the one that's nice and easy to hang out with. But when it comes down to it, I'm never the person someone calls first. I'm not the best friend, the ride or die, the person they can't wait to text when something happens. I'm just there, always included, never prioritized. It's such a mind fuck because technically I have friends, I'm not isolated, but I still feel invisible. I'll be standing right there laughing with everyone and still feel like an extra in my own life. Like I'm the supporting character in their story, but never the main one in mine. And yeah, it hurts. It fucking hurts watching everyone else pair off, have their person while I'm the one left lingering in the background. I'm good enough for everyone, but not special enough for anyone.

Bro, August was probably the craziest month in history. Like I don't even think historians are gonna know how to write this down. We literally got two new seasons in one month. An immortal person casually existing, a priest who went to hell and actually threw hands with Satan, radioactive nuclear spiders and then somehow the UK decided to spawn human sized rat. Oh, and the Black Plague made a comeback in 2025. But wait, it gets worse. Aliens are apparently landing in November. Citra out here building a 10 foot tall Terminator, animatronic, the Boo Boo dolls confirmed to be affiliated with the Devil. Ice cream trucks mysteriously appearing again like it's 2006. The iPhone 17 straight up leak. And then Roblox. Bro, Roblox was on another level of insanity. They said he sent an assist letter to SLEP which backfired so hard that SLEP actually clapped back. Roblox stock tanked by $12 billion. He dropped an AI generated apology. Chris Hanson pulled up, law by Mike pulled up and even the state of Louisiana started suing Roblox. Then out of nowhere, the US congressman gets involved. Roblox starts getting banned in countries like Qatar and Indonesia. And both the US and UK governments are now investigating Roblox for safety issues. While all this chaos is happening, creators like kreekraft are leaving the star program. And the best news of all, I got nearly 80,000 people to subscribe to my channel this month. Bro, August wasn't a month, it was An entire Netflix series.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I'd divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2 3 years, max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation. To our eight year olds, that first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home, and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decision. It's no more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curveball. Our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year two brought unexpected changes. Without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to enjoy My children. Year three changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partner ship could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually, she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught Skyler to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her bonus mom. Their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes, and tucked them in at night. Year five was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. In their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and be being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year six, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward. After three Years of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp from the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she own

On a school trip, my best friend asked, if you had to choose between your mom and girlfriend to live, who would you pick? I responded, bros before hoes, but moms before all. And everyone cracked up. Jason didn't smile, though. His face drained of color like I just confessed to murder. He grabbed all his stuff and moved 3 rows up the school bus without a word. Jason, what's wrong? I was just kidding. I called after him, but he wouldn't turn around. That's when I heard it stay. Casey, my girlfriend's best friend, was crying her eyes out in the back row. When I turned to look, her friend whispered urgently in her ear and she glanced at me before crying harder. Okay, hey, that was definitely weird. I started to wonder whether my joke was really that offensive. That's when my phone buzzed. Three missed calls from dad, but there was no signal. And at the red light, I caught the bus driver wiping his eyes in the rearview mirror. In my three years of knowing him, the most emotion he'd shown was mild annoyance when kids left trash on the seats. A cold feeling crept into my stomach. I got up to go talk to Jason, but Missus Unfitzharris blocked the aisle. Sit down. We're moving. I just need to sit down. I'd never heard her voice like that. I sat. But the second we got to the destination, I cornered Jason. Dude, what is going On he backed away. Nothing. I just, I need space, bruh. I was just kidding. I don't know if I'd pick my mom or my girlfriend. Why did you have to tell everyone what I said? Sid appeared out of nowhere and pulled me aside. Our team captain who never said more.

I told my mom that I'm disgusted by and ashamed of my sister. It started when my sister Chloe came home crying because her boyfriend Jake dumped her. She's 25 and I'm 17, but she always acts like she's the victim in every situation. This time was different, though. She kept saying Jake was horrible and cruel. But when I asked what happened, she got all shifty. He said he broke up with her out of nowhere and kicked her out of his apartment. But then she mentioned she still had keys to his place because she forgot to give them back the next day. She left early in the morning and came back with this huge golden retriever. I recognized him immediately. It was Buster, Jake's dog. Jake love that dog more than anything. When his grandpa died last year, Buster was the only thing that helped him through it. I asked Chloe why she had Buster and she got this weird smile on her face. She said Jake didn't deserve to keep him since he broke her heart. Then she said something that made my stomach drop. She told me she was going to take Buster to the vet tomorrow to put him down as payback for what Jake did to her. I couldn't believe what I was hearing. This dog was completely healthy and happy, just confused about being in a new place. Buster kept looking around for Jake and whining by the door. It was heartbreaking. I told Chloe she was being insane and she couldn't just kill someone's dog because she was upset. She laughed and said Jake should have thought about that before he decided to hurt her. Then she said if I told anyone, she'd make sure I regretted it. That night I couldn't sleep, kept thinking about Buster and how scared he must be. Around 2:00am, I heard Chloe on the phone with someone probably making the vet appointment. I knew I had to do something. The next morning, Chloe left for work and told mom she was taking Buster for a walk later. Mom didn't know the whole story. Chloe just said Jake asked her to watch his dog for a few days. As soon as both of them were gone, I called Jake. He picked up on the first ring and sounded terrible. I told him Chloe had Buster and was planning to put him down today. He went completely silent for like 10 seconds, then started freaking out. He said he'd been looking everywhere for Buster and thought maybe he got out somehow. I told Jake to come over now while Chloe was at work. He was at our house in 15 minutes. When he saw Buster, he literally started crying. Buster went crazy with excitement, jumping all over him and licking his face. I opened the door and Jake carried his dog out to his car. Before he left, Jake told me what really happened with Chloe. She Didn't just get dumped. She cheated on him with his best friend, Marcus. When Jake found out, he broke up with her and told her to move out. She stole Buster on her way out and left Jake's spare key on the counter so he thought she was being mature about the breakup. A few hours later, Chloe came home and went straight to look for Buster when she couldn't find him. She started screaming my name. She found me in my room and absolutely lost it. She called me a traitor and said I had no right to interfere in her business. Then mom came home and asked what all the yelling was about. Chloe told her I let some guy steal her dog. She made it sound like I just gave away her pet to a random stranger. Mom looked.

I was about to knock on my parents door when I heard them tell my brother, don't worry about the debt. We'll make your sister pay. She'll never say no to family. I froze with the grocery bags in my hands. Through the kitchen window, I could see them all sitting around the table. Mom, dad, and my brother. Landon Harper's got that new job, dad was saying. Making good money now. We'll just tell her it's for Mom's surgery. Mom nodded. She gave us 12,000 for the roof last year, no questions asked. My stomach dropped. There was no roof repair. I'd seen the receipts myself. They'd used my money for Landon's gambling debts. How much this time? Mom asked. 50,000, Landon said casually, maybe 60 if we play it right. Tell her the cancer came back. Cancer? They were going to fake cancer to steal from me. I backed away slowly, my mind racing. The cancer scare from two years ago, the one that made me liquidate my retirement fund to pay for experimental. Had that been fake, too? I thought about all the times I'd helped. A car accident that wasn't covered by insurance. Landon's business that needed startup capital. Mom's dental work, Dad's back surgery. $57,000 over five years. All because I thought I was being a good daughter. Every family gathering, they raised me for being so generous. Behind my back, they were laughing at how easy I was to manipulate. I got in my Car and drove straight to the bank. I'd like to close all my accounts, I told the teller. All of them. Miss every single one. And I need cashiers checks for the full amount. documentation of every transaction I've made to these three people over the past five years. That evening, Landon called, right on schedule. Hey, sis, can you come over tomorrow? Mom has some news about her health. His voice had that practiced concern, the same tone he'd used for every fake emergency. Sure, I said sweetly. I'll bring the whole family something special. I spent that night making copies of everything. Bank statements, medical records I'd helped to pay for. Receipts from Landon's failed ventures. Five years of financial manipulation, all documented. The next day, I

Why are people mocking Charlie Kirk's death like it's some kind of joke? The man was gunned down in front of his wife and daughter. And instead of taking a second to acknowledge how horrifying that is, people are online making memes and throwing around cheap punch lines like his life was entertaining. He wasn't just a political figure on a stage. He was a husband and a father. And his daughter literally watched her dad collapse in front of her. Imagine being that kid one day, scrolling online and seeing thousands of strangers laughing about the worst moment of your life. You don't have to agree with his politics. You don't have to support anything he stood for. But celebrating a man's murder in front of his family isn't some clever protest. It's cruelty. Everyone talks about empathy and compassion until it's someone they disagree with. Then suddenly all that moral high ground disappears and death becomes a punchline. That's not justice. That's just heartlessness disguised as politics. Snoopy.

My wife said, I don't owe you intimacy. So I showed her what life looks like when I stop owing her love, effort, and commitment. We've been married eight years. Eight years of working overtime for our house, down payment, canceling plans when she needed me home, spending weekends fixing things to make her life easier. I thought I was being considerate, spirit, offering to set aside work and distractions to focus on us instead of appreciation. I got a sharp, dismissive response. Her tone was cold, almost rehearsed. I don't owe you intimacy, she said, arms crossed, eyes locked on me like she was daring me to challenge her. At first I thought I'd misheard. What does that even mean? I asked, half laughing, half nervous. She didn't flinch. It means exactly what it sounds like. I'm tired of you acting like it's some kind of obligation. Just because we're married doesn't mean I owe you anything. I felt like the ground had been ripped out from under me. Eight years of sacrifices and working myself to exhaustion, and now she was telling me my feelings and needs didn't matter. That the foundation of our marriage, trust in timidity partnership, was apparently optional. The fight didn't last much longer. She walked out, leaving me standing there with my thoughts racing. By morning, my frustration had turned into resolve. If she didn't owe me intimacy, then maybe I didn't owe her the endless sacrifices I've been making.

My friend shamed me for not wearing makeup, so I showed up to her wedding completely glammed up. My friend Katie always had something to say about my face. Every time we hung out, she'd make these little comments like you'd look so much better with just some mascara or I have lipstick that would really help you out. I kept brushing it off because we've been friends since middle school and I figured she meant well. But then came her engagement party last month. I showed up in a nice dress, hair done, feeling good about myself. Katie took one look at me and said, oh, honey, you really should have told me you weren't doing makeup. I would have brought my kit. She said it loud enough for everyone to hear, including her fiance's family, who I was meeting for the first time. I felt my face turn red. Her mom even chimed in saying, Katie's right, dear. A little color would really brighten you up. I spent the whole night feeling like everyone was staring at my bare face. Katie kept introducing me as her natural friend with this fake sweet smile. That night I texted my sister about it. She was furious and said Katie was being a total jerk. Then she offered to do my makeup for the wedding since she works at Sephora. I told her no at first because I didn't want to be petty. But she convinced me that looking good wasn't About Katie. It was about me feeling confident. So two weeks before the wedding, my sister and I went shopping. We got everything, foundation, concealer, eyeshadow, palettes, the works. She taught me how to do a full glam look that made my eyes pop and my skin look flawless. We practiced three times until I could do it myself. Morning of Katie's wedding, I woke up at 6:00am to start getting ready. I did my makeup exactly like my sister taught me, then put on this stunning blue dress I've been saving for a special occasion. When I looked in the mirror, I barely recognized myself. I looked amazing. I got to the church early and found my seat.

When did your husband's female friend finally cross the line? My husband's friend Kate always had to be the main character in every situation. When someone else had good news, Kate suddenly had better news. At group dinners, she'd hijack any conversation within five minutes. I couldn't stand her, but I put up with it because she and Zach had been friends since college. After my husband and I announced our pregnancy at 12 weeks, things with Kate got really weird. Suddenly, Kate was everywhere we went sporting a small baby bump. She showed up at our favorite brunch spot rubbing her belly. She enrolled in our exact prenatal yoga class. She even switched to our OB practice. Nobody questioned it because these things happen, and women get pregnant at the same time, she posted weekly bump photos on Instagram, and everyone congratulated her just like they did me. Three months in, one of our friends mentioned something strange at a girl's night. She said Kate's belly looked bigger the previous Tuesday at book club than it did at Saturday's barbecue. When she brought it up, Kate burst into tears about how cruel it was to comment on a pregnant woman's body. She went on about water retention and bloating and how pregnant women deal with enough judgment without their friends piling on. Our friend felt terrible and apologized foolishly while the rest of us comforted Kate. After that night, nobody dared mention anything about her appearance again, even though I started noticing her bump size seemed to fluctuate, too. That's when things got uncomfortable. Kate started making comments about how wild it was that we got pregnant around the same time. She'd joke about our babies being best friends, or maybe even more than friends someday. Then the jokes got stranger, like when she said pregnancy Brain made her forget exactly when she conceived and wasn't it funny how close our due dates were? She started showing up at every single appointment Zach and I had, always in the waiting room when we arrived, claiming her appointment was right before or after hours. During our maternity photo shoot at the park, she appeared with her own photographer, saying what a coincidence that she booked the same spot. The photographer later told me Kate had called asking what time we'd be there. Everything exploded at my baby shower. My. My sister threw this beautiful garden party with all our family and friends there to celebrate. Halfway through opening gifts, Kate stood up and clinked her glass to make an announcement. With tears streaming down her face, she placed her hand on her belly and said, I have the most wonderful news to share with everyone. Zack and I are having a baby together! The entire party gasped, and she continued with a huge smile, I know this is unconventional, but isn't it beautiful that our babies will be siblings?

Alright, bro, Halloween 2025 and creativity is not mixing together because I just saw a TikTok where there's outfit idea for Halloween and it's just basic clothes with literal no creativity has put in like, oh yeah, I wanna be Jeff the killer. So I just put on a white T-shirt, red pants and pair of sneaker and boom, there you go. Jeff the killer you can get from Shein. Like, bro, nobody is using this crap. I need something scary, not basic and cute. Like bro, how about if I wanna be Iron Man? You're gonna suggest me a plain red T-shirt and call it a day? Like, where's the creativity? Did it just ran away? I remember back then there was costume makeup and a lot of creativity is put into it. But this year is just plain shirt and Jean. Like bro, you ain't giving out outfit ideas, you're giving out what to wear on a regular day. Like bro, when Halloween comes, I better see someone with a costume that is just perfection, not a plain shirt and jeans or at least use makeup. Damn it, did we just enter an era where we turn cute instead of being scary or act like a psychopath so you can get candy? Like, come on, I better not see anyone using this basic idea or I'm going to start questioning about our creativity.

My boyfriend said I was too clingy at parties, so I gave him all the space he wanted. Logan had been complaining for weeks that I hovered too much. When we went out at his company's holiday party, he pulled me aside near the coat check. Listen. Tonight, can you just not be so attached to me? My coworkers think it's weird how you're always by my side. Just mingle on your own. For once, I smiled sweetly. Of course, babe, I'll give you tons of space. Really? You're not upset? Not at all. You want independence at parties? You got it. The party was at this upscale rooftop venue, open bar, DJ, the Works. Logan immediately ditched me to bro out with his work buddies, leaving me by the entrance. Perfect. I walked straight to the bar where his boss, Thomas, was getting drinks. Emily, where's Logan? Oh, he wanted space. Tonight, I'm flying solo. Thomas looked confused at his own company party. He says I'm too clingy, didn't want me cramping his style. Thomas's wife, Diane overheard. He left you alone. How rude. No worries. I'll just entertain myself. And I did. I ended up in a fascinating conversation with the CFO about cryptocurrency. Then the head of HR pulled me into their group to settle a debate about true crime podcasts. I was having a genuinely great time. An hour in, I caught Logan's eye across the room. He was with his bros but kept glancing over As I laughed with his supervisors, then the DJ started playing salsa music. This gorgeous guy from accounting, Javier, asked if I could dance. I'd love to. We tore up that dance floor. Turns out Javier was a semi professional dancer. He spun me, dipped me the whole nine yards. Proud form to watch. Logan appeared suddenly. Hey, maybe we should, oh, am I being too clingy? I asked mid spin. No, I just, great. Then you won't mind if I keep dancing. Javier dipped me dramatically. The crowd cheered. Logan retreated to the bar Downing whiskey with his confused buddies. Later, the CEO's wife pulled me aside. You're Logan's girlfriend. We need to talk. She dragged me to her table full of executives wives. They immediately adopted me, pouring champagne and gossiping about everyone. Logan usually brags about you non stop. One said, where is he? He needed guy time. Apparently I hover. They exchanged looks. Men are idiots, the CEO's wife declared, raising her glass. Toasted to that. Logan kept trying to approach, but every time he got close, someone else would pull me into conversation. His female co workers wanted workout tips. The it guys needed restaurant recommendations. Even the janitor asked for relationship advice. Everyone loved me except Logan who looked increasingly miserable. Then came the speeches. CEO grabbed the mic thanking everyone for their hard work. Special shout out to Emily for bringing such amazing energy tonight. Logan, you're a lucky man. Everyone clapped looking Around for Logan. He was sulking by the bathroom. Where's Logan? The CEO asked into the mic. He wanted space. So when yelled laughter erupted, the CEO's wife grabbed the mic. Well, his loss. Emily's been the life of the party. More cheering. Logan's face went red. Around midnight, the party was winding down. I was.

I got my family to do a swear tax after my dad told me off for swearing. So my dad has this mouth like a sailor. Every other word out of his mouth is some form of curse word. He drops F bombs at breakfast, calls drivers idiots when we're in the car, and basically swears more than anyone I know. It's been like this my whole life. Last week I'm in the kitchen making a sandwich and I dropped the Mayo jar. It smashes everywhere and I go, oh, shit, not again. Pretty normal reaction. Action, right? Wrong. My dad comes storming in like I just committed murder. Watch your language, young lady. I don't want to hear that garbage coming out of your mouth again. I just stared at him. This is the same guy who stubbed his toe yesterday and yelled son of a bitch, bastard, piece of shit table loud enough for the neighbors to hear. But somehow me saying shit once is crossing the line. Are you serious right now, dad? Dead serious. You're better than that. That's when I got the idea. If you wanted to please my language, fine. But fair is fair. Okay, dad, you're right. Swearing is bad. So let's all stop starting now. Anyone who swears in this house pays $5 into a jar. Family swear tax. He laughed like it was a joke. Sure, honey, whatever makes you happy. I grabbed an empty pickle jar from the recycling and Wrote swear jar on it with a Sharpie, put it right on the kitchen counter where everyone could see it. Day one was amazing. Dad walks into the kitchen that morning, sees the coffee pot is empty.

Have you ever been happy about intentionally manipulating someone? Every Thursday for three years, I told my wife Becca the same thing. I'm going to hang with the boys tonight. Be back around midnight. Truth is, I was driving to the cinema to watch movies alone because I just needed some me time. But then two months ago, my movie ended abruptly and I came home two hours earlier than planned. When I turned onto our street, there was a black Infinity in our driveway. My heart stopped as I watched back all the footage from our doorbell camera and saw a man getting out of the car and walk. Hang up like he done it before. Becca opened. Before he could ring, they kissed. The kind where her hand went to his neck. My stomach dropped. I wanted to burst through that door and confront them, but I decided on the spot that that would be too kind. Needed to do something else. Something that would destroy her. So I drove around until 12:30 and walked in with a story about Tony getting drunk. Becca was showering. Hey, babe. How was your night? Good. You know how it is. Next two Thursdays, I kept my routine, but park down the street at 8:30 to watch. At the same time, the same car pulled up. I zoomed in on the ring footage, and that's when it hit me. The man was Mark. Mark, who supposedly moved to Seattle two years Ago, my knees were shaking, but I took screenshots and sent them to my lawyer to further build my case. When I was confident enough that I had everything basically set up, I dropped the bomb. Becca was going on about her fake plans for when I left for Boys Night, when I randomly blurted out, you know who I miss? Mark. That guy and I used to have so much fun before he moved to Seattle. Her fork stopped halfway to her mouth just for a second. Yeah, Mark was great. You guys still text, though, right? Sometimes. The next morning, she woke up different, with this nervous energy. She made some phone calls behind closed doors. And since it was Thursday, during lunch, she texted, what time are you heading out tonight? She never asked before, so I knew. The comment about Mark got her. Probably 7:30. Why? Just wondering. The guys doing anything special? Same old. After work. She was cooking in full makeup. You look nice, I said. Just felt like making an effort for you to come home to. But she kept checking her phone and setting it down, then picking it back up. At 7:15, she practically. He pushed me out. Don't want you to be late. Tell everyone I say hi. I drove to my regular spot down the street where I watched them, but this time, there was no car that showed up. And at nine fifteen, becca's own car pulled out. I followed her. First stop, o'malley's sports bar, where she thought i'd be. She walked in confidently, then came out five minutes later looking confused, checking her phone, scanning the parking lot. Then she got back in her car. Her second stop, the dugout, another sports bar. Through the windows, I watched her walk the entire place, moving table to table, even checking the bathroom entrance area. She showed her phone to a waitress, who shrugged. Back to the car, more frantic phone checking. Third stop, Buffalo Wild Wings. She stayed longer this time, 15 minutes. I could see her at the bar talking to the manager, showing him something on her phone, probably my picture. He shook his head, pointed to their mostly empty tables. Thursday wasn't exactly Prime Sports Bar night. Fourth stop, the dive bar where Tony actually used to drag us. She went straight to the bartender. I slipped in through the side door, ducked into the hallway by the bathrooms, heard her say, every Thursday night, group of guys, probably five or six of them, loud. One of them looks like this. The bartender studied her phone. Thursday is our slowest night. I definitely remember a regular group. Sorry. She left looking frustrated, sat in her car for five minutes typing furiously. Then she drove to the AMC theater. I gave her a 10 minute head start, then walk in through the side entrance. She was at the concession stand talking to the teenage manager. Showed her phone again. He pointed toward the theaters. She went to check each one, opening doors, scanning the sparse Thursday night crowds. I went back to my car. Twenty minutes later, she emerged, looking defeated. Sat in her car for another 10 minutes. Through her rear window, I could see her on the phone, gesturing with her free hand. Probably calling Mark. Probably saying she couldn't find me anywhere. That maybe I knew that Thursday nights might not be safe anymore. She even drove by two more bar on the way home. Quick stops, desperate checks. When I got home at my usual time, she was on the couch with. As always. Yeah. Where exactly did you guys go? Oh, Malley's. Why? Her jaw clenched. No reason. Just curious. Was it busy? Pretty dead, actually. Who all was there? Haven't heard their names in a while. The usual.
NA

Bro, I just realized that red is the only color in the alphabet with the same numbers and letters and numbers. Like, think about it. R is the 18th letter in the alphabet. E is the 5th. D is the fourth. Add that up, that's 27. Now hear me out. 2 + 7 = 9. And what month are we in right now? That's right. September, the ninth month. This is actually insane. And if you flip the nine upside down, you get a six. Put that next to the seven we just had. Six, seven. Same exact number we've been seeing all year. This is literally massive news for the unemployed.

If there's an earthquake, just get on a plane. Like, bro, the ground is the one having a seizure, not the sky. Why are you crying in your collapsing house when Spirit Airlines is right there? Imagine everyone getting crushed under rubble while you're 30,000 feet in the air. Skill issue. Honestly, if earthquakes scare you, just become a pilot. That way you can crash into the fault line yourself and speed run the ricter scale. Bro said earthquake killed thousands. No, that was me hitting autopilot. Shut your fucking mouth.

My ex left me and our kids with a note saying she'd be back in a few years. She returned 6 years later to find I divorced her and moved on. The note was taped to our bathroom mirror. Going to live with my sister in California. Need space to figure things out. Back in 2, 3 years Max. Change the locks. She left while I was at work and the twins were at school. No goodbye, no explanation to our 8 year olds. That first night was brutal. Skyler kept asking when Mommy was coming home and Walter just stared at his untouched dinner. I had no idea how to explain that their mother had essentially abandoned them for a midlife crisis. But something weird happened after the initial shock wore off. Our house became peaceful. No more constant arguing about money. No more her undermining my parenting decision missions. No more walking on eggshells around her mood swings. Year one was learning mode. I figured out how to braid Skyler's hair after watching YouTube tutorials for hours. I taught Walter to throw a curve ball our backyard. We established routines that actually worked. Homework at the kitchen table, then dinner together every night. Year 2 brought unexpected changes without the stress of a failing marriage. I got promoted at work. The kids grades improved dramatically. We started family game nights and camping trips. I realized I've been so focused on fixing my marriage that I'd forgotten how to Enjoy my children. Year 3 changed everything. At Walter's baseball game, I met Eleanor, another single parent. She was a third grade teacher, patient and kind. When Skyler spilled juice all over herself, Eleanor calmly helped clean her up without making a big deal about it. That small moment showed me what partner ship could actually look like. Eleanor and I took things incredibly slow. The kids had been through enough upheaval. But gradually she became part of our routine. She helped with homework, taught sky to bake cookies, and never once tried to replace their mother. Just added love to our family. Year 4, Eleanor moved in. The transition was seamless because the kids genuinely adored her. They started calling her Bonus Mom, their own idea. She attended every school event, packed their lunches with little encouraging notes and tucked them in at night. Year 5 was magical. Eleanor and I got married in our backyard. Skyler and Walter insisted on walking her down the aisle together. Their speeches, they thanked her for making dad smile again and being the mom who stayed. There wasn't a dry eye in the house. By year 6, our life had completely transformed. We bought a bigger house with a proper yard. The kids were thriving. Skyler made honor roll. Walter was team captain. Eleanor had legally adopted them after my ex's parental rights were terminated for abandonment. We were a real family. The legal process had been surprisingly straightforward after three years. Of zero contact. Court classified it as voluntary abandonment. Eleanor's adoption paperwork went through without a hitch. The kids were ecstatic to officially change their last names to match ours. Last Tuesday, everything changed again. I was making coffee when I heard Eleanor gasp in the living room. Through the window, we watched my ex climbing out of a U Haul truck, pulling suitcases toward our front door. She still had our old house key. She walked straight into our kitchen like she owned the place. Eleanor was packing the twins lunches for.

Holy shit. What is wrong with September? It's only been 11 days and the world is completely off its fucking rocker. Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family. David was found with a body in his car. A Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway. And now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Like, can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. The scene was so bloody and gruesome, it's insane. A Ukrainian girl gets stabbed on a train in Charlotte. She escaped a literal war, came here to be safe and still got killed because this planet has zero peace. Then D4D has a whole body in his car, like not a metaphorical one, an actual human body in a bag in his trunk. And this dude just casually performed like he didn't have a horror movie in his backseat. What the hell? And even outside all of that, Elon Musk is no longer the richest person in the world, losing his top spot to a rival tech CEO, showing how unstable everything feels right now, even at the highest levels. It's like every time I open my phone, reality speed runs another tragedy. Like, bro, it's been 11 days. September just started. I thought my only problem this month would be math class, but no, apparently It's full blown world collapse. Society isn't just cooked, it's burnt to ash.

Did you start taking girls Support girls more seriously? I was halfway through Saturday morning spin at Cycle Soul Clenching to keep my tampon inside of me when I noticed the blonde girl in front of me facetiming my boyfriend of four years. Can't wait to see you tonight, beautiful, he whispered. I vomited in my mouth. I can't believe we've been dating for three months already. She responded like, hello, Britney. Our instructor who always wore the cutest sets saw me crying and immediately cut her playlist. Hey, hon, are you doing okay? That's my man. I pointed at the screen where Blake was now shirtless making breakfast. The entire studio went silent, 25 girls in coordinating workout sets just staring. The blonde girl immediately hung up and turned around. Wait, girl, I'm so sorry. I swear I didn't know. Every single girl started climbing off their bikes. Someone handed me a liquid IV. Someone else had tissues, the good ones with lotion. Another girl was already fixing my mascara with her emergency makeup kit. Four years, Natalie shrieked. This absolute trash man has been with her for four years. The blonde Isabella looked like she was gonna throw up her green juice. I met him on Bumble and he said he just got out of something casual. Casual. The entire room erupted. They found his Instagram and followed in seconds. The most recent photo was literally a picture of us holding hands by the beach with the caption L O m L this absolute queen with sleeve tattoos and perfect and liner just said call his sister speaker now my hands were shaking as I found Ellie's contact. She spoke first hey babe how's been? Did you try that new protein smoothie place? After Ellie my voice voice cracked Blake's facetiming another girl they've been together for three months the silence was louder than when a boy starts showing you his camera roll on the first date girl, don't play are you being effing for real right now? I turned on Facetime and showed myself crying my eyes out and that's when she started shouting I'm getting my mom and we're coming right now don't effing move she hung up and I just stared at my phone like okay, Ellie kind of ate oh, this is about to be good someone whispered Isabella and I were clutching each other's hands neither of us blaming each other the entire class was hyping me up and telling me I deserve better teenager in the corner came up to me and said girl even while crying your skin is glowing let that crusty man go back to picking girls who are actually in his league the class leader Bethany shouted your hot girl era starts now now even the quiet girl said girl you were really gonna give that receding hairline your best years that one made me laugh and y'all when that door flew open it was like Real Housewives Met Crazy Rich Asians. Ellie strutted in with her Balenciaga bag. Mrs. A. Leek in her Saturday costar fit but make it fashion. Her Aunt Linda, who I didn't even know was coming, had her Cartier sunglasses on indoors. Where is she? Mrs. Leek's voice could have cut diamonds. She saw me, saw Isabella. I watched her perfectly microbladed brows go through the five stages of grief in real time. Ellie, call your brother now, mom. Maybe we should now. The way Ellie's acrylics clicked on her phone screen was aggressive. What? Blake's annoyed voice came through the speaker. Get your butt down to cycle soul.

What happened when my mom demanded 24 7 access to my phone? When I turned 15, my mom went from strict to straight up paranoid. One night after dinner, she plopped down next to me with this weird smile and said she was installing a family safety app on my phone. I watched her tap away, giving herself access to everything. My location, photos, texts, even my drafts on social media. It's just to keep you safe, honey, she said, handing my phone back like nothing had changed. But everything had changed. It felt like having a stalker who lived in my house. At first I tried to be cool about it. Maybe it would calm her down, right? Wrong. Things got insane fast. She text me in the middle of conversations asking who I was with. Comment on memes I haven't even posted yet because she was reading my drafts. The worst part? She started replying to my friends pretending to be me. My buddy Jake texted asking if I wanted to hang out, and my mom replied, sure. Sure thing, buddy! With way too many exclamation points. Jake called me laughing, asking why I was texting like a soccer mom. I had no idea what he meant until I checked my messages. Then came the day that broke me. I was in history class when Mrs. Wilson pulled me aside. Looked uncomfortable as hell. Liam, your mother called the school. She's concerned about some message you sent about Me. My stomach dropped. I knew exactly what she meant. I texted my best friend Kyle the night before, joking about how our history teacher's haircut looked like she stuck her finger in an electrical socket. It was just good friend stuff, not meant for anyone else. But my mom had read it and called the school to complain about my private joke. I wanted to disappear into the floor. By lunch, Kyle wasn't talking to me. Neither was Jake. Word got around that my mom was reading everything, and suddenly nobody wanted to text me anymore. Some kids even blocked me. It was like my social life had a disease. And the disease was my mom. That night, I stared at my phone, feeling trapped. But then I noticed something. The tracking app worked both ways. It log every time someone access the account. I spent hours studying those logs, and what I found made my skin crawl. My mom wasn't just checking my phone during the day. She was logging in 1 a m, 2 a m, even 3 a m. She was forwarding my messages to her laptop. She was screenshotting my photos. She was living inside my phone 24 7. So I came up with a plan. I created a fake friend named Daniel, made up this whole persona, gave him a backstory. Even found some random photos online to use as his profile pic on a group chat with myself.

Did you know that the people who are gay can actually run faster than the people who are dead? This is because dead people can't walk. Did you also know that the video you are watching right now is actually seen by your eyes? And did you know that if you sneeze in a room when there is no one around, there is a 100% chance that no one has heard it? Did you know that the blackest and the whitest person in the world lives here on earth? And did you also know that you can't buy a Rolls Royce because you are broke? But have you ever realised that the world record for being underwater the longest is actually held by a fish? Also, did you know that if you throw yourself into a pool, the water that touches you will actually make you wet? And did you know that there are more ships on the water than there are on the sun? But did you know that if you stop using your phone, there is a 100% chance that you can still breathe? Did you know that a day is 24 hours long? Because that's how long it takes for the earth to spin once. Did you know that if you talk to your plants, they won't talk back? Did you know that if you read this entire list of facts, you're officially awesome?

So apparently a high school in Colorado just went through a really tragic incident. The school just outside of Denver had more than 100 police officers rushed to the scene after reports of violence broke out on campus. Right now, three students in, including the suspect, are in critical condition at the hospital. What's even more shocking is that officials aren't even sure if the suspect was old enough to drive. One student who was just eating his lunch outside said the only thought that ran through his head was, no way this is happening. This feels one in a million. It's such a heartbreaking situation.

Charlie Kirk was killed in front of his family, David was found with a body in his car, a Ukrainian girl was stabbed on the subway, and now Elon Musk isn't even the richest man on the planet anymore. Like, can we chill for one second? First, Charlie Kirk got shot during a speech in Utah. He was literally in front of his wife and kids when a bullet entered his artery through his neck. If I ever become an astronaut, I swear I'm flying straight to the sun. And hear me out. NASA keeps saying the sun is too hot. Like, bro, just go at night when it's dark. Problem solved. Y'all really got billion dollar rockets but can't figure out basic common sense. The sun isn't even out when it's dark, so it's obviously cooler. These scientists overthinking it like Thermal radiation and fusion core. Nah, bro, just pull up when it's sleeping. Imagine spending 8 years in astronaut school just to forget that the sun literally goes away half the day. Couldn't be me. Shut up.

My school is forcing me to delete my YouTube channel. After the video exposing my bullies went viral, my principal randomly called me into his office saying he wanted to talk. So I'm thinking, finally, those girls are about to get punished for the public humiliation they caused me. But I couldn't have been more wrong. I walk in the room and see the two girls already sitting there with my video playing on the principal's laptop. And I'm just standing there getting ready for the pure satisfaction of watching their punishment unfold. But instead, he suddenly turns to me, slams his hand on his desk and goes, do you know how much harassment you've caused for these girls, bro? These girls bullied me for days, but you're telling me I'm the one getting punished for it? And if that wasn't bad enough, that's when he gave me the decision. You need to either stop posting and delete these hateful videos or I'll have no choice but to suspend you if I should keep posting. Subscribe, please.

How the fuck did Charlie Kirk get shot? Like bro was just sitting at a table answering questions and suddenly it's boom. That wasn't call of duty. That was hardcore real life mode. One bullet straight to the neck and the whole event turned into Black Friday at Walmart. People running, screaming, folding chairs flying. And I made the mistake of seeing the uncensored video. Bro, I didn't even blink. I just sat there frozen. That was not a clip. That was a trauma download. My brain caught a virus. I swear I can still hear the audio when I close my eyes now. Every time I scroll, it pops up again. People keep reposting it, slowing it down, zooming in like I didn't already get PTSD on the first watch. At this point, I'm traumatized. I need a therapist and especially a memory eraser. I didn't watch a video. I unlocked a curse.

Why don't homeless people just try and rob a bank? Like hear me out. If they're successful, they're instantly rich. No more sleeping under bridges. They're straight up balling. But if they fail, what happens? Jail, which is basically free food, free bed, free shelter, free Wi-Fi if you're lucky. That's literally a win win situation, bro. Worst case scenario, you end up with three meals a day and a roommate named Big Mike. Best case scenario, you're the next Elon Musk, but without the lawsuit. Honestly, I don't get why no one's speed running this strategy. It sounds more efficient than half the self improvement TikToks I see.
